title: Spits water when boiling
body: I have been using my new kettle for a few days now. It is very easy and comfortable to pour, which was my biggest need. My only problem is that water spits out of the spout when it reaches a boil. It doesnt have to be full and it doesn't matter which burner I have it on. I have to make sure that the spout is pointed away from me, and have to clean up a puddle of water on the stove. I'm keeping this for the pouring part, but will have to transfer the hot water from my other kettle since I dont want to have this one on the stove.

title: Works well - only issue is loose lid
body:
The kettle looks good, boils water well and the handle stays perfectly cool. I have the 1.2L version - it boils quickly on my induction range and gives lots of control over pour speed.

My only complaint is that the lid is not very secure and when the water starts to boil, the lid tends to rise out of the kettle. I did purchase a second kettle to see if the issue was specific to mine but the second one had the same problem.

Overall I like the kettle well enough to keep it.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 23 de julio de 2023

title: Laudable kettle
body:
I bought this kettle recently totally based on the previous reviews here, and I must say that I am very glad that I did. The listing photographs are a very accurate representation and I'm sure most people will agree that the kettle looks good, with lots of smooth curves and a good design. The steel looks to be of a good quality, although there is some natural discolouration on the bottom of the kettle through use. The kettle weighs just over 400 grams when empty, which is pretty light for a kettle in my experience, making it easy to handle and manoeuvre. The lid is easily removed and replaced, with the three holes in it letting steam escape to let you know when the water is boiling. Water boils pretty quickly, certainly comparing well to all of the other kettles that I have owned recently. The spout is long and thin, but seems securely attached to the kettle and is not at all loose. I love the smooth and extremely controlled, accurate way you can pour water from the spout. When you start pouring other kettles, the water can splash a little due to a poorly designed spout, but no such problems here. As you can probably imagine, you can't pour a full kettle of water in three seconds due to the thin nature of the spout.

Highly recommended.

title: Super Verarbeitung und praktisch!
body: Wir nutzen den Edelstahl Wasserkessel (sowie Tassen Filter und TÃ¼ten von Hario) immer beim Camping, weil er so super auf die Flamme der KÃ¼che im Camper passt. Trotz der offenen Flamme wird der Griff nicht heiÃŸ und durch die dÃ¼nne AusgieÃŸÃ¶ffnung ist er prÃ¤zise und einfach zu handhaben. Es kleckert nichts oder tropft heiÃŸes Wasser irgendwo hin. Nach 3 Jahren intensiver Benutzung immernoch wie am ersten Tag und weder unansehnlich noch defekt. Daheim fliegt er in den GeschirrspÃ¼ler und ist danach wieder chic! Auch aufgrund der GrÃ¶ÃŸe gut zu verstauen! Wir hatten uns absichtlich fÃ¼r ihn aus Edelstahl entschieden und nicht irgendwas Faltbares aus Silikon etc ausgesucht. Und es auch keine Sekunde bereut! Der Inhalt reicht fÃ¼r 3 Tassen Kaffee, ausreichend fÃ¼r uns!
author: Korbinian O.
date: Revisado en Alemania el 5 de marzo de 2021

title: High Quality Basic Stovetop Kettle!
body:
I am no stranger to Hario products, I have found that almost all of them may be somewhat simplistic, but they are extremely functional. Ive been using this for the last month and I have been loving it.

Some helpful information:

I bought the 1.2L model and it is made in Japan, its stamped right there on the bottom of the kettle.
The steel seems to be high quality, absolutely no rusting, even if it has had water in it 80-90% of the time.
The kettle is induction compatible, works great on my induction stove.
It lists 1.2L as the capacity, do remember that boiling water is quite violent, so really, you can safely boil about 800ml or so, maybe up to about 1l. You can easily store and serve up to about 1.2l in it.

I have exclusively used bottled water in the kettle, as the local water here is ultra hard and is not great for making coffee or tea, and I am unable to install a proper filtration system that is able to reduce the hardness.

I havent had to deep clean the thing since ive been using relatively clean water in it, but I imagine that its not very hard, just bring it to a boil with some citric acid if you have scale issues.

As to using the kettle, it pours beautifully, a nice even stream that doesnt dribble. The handle stays nice and cool, and is comfortable to use. It works great for my coffee-making, be it with my french press, V60, or my Aeropress. I can imagine that its great for making tea as well.

As a bit of helpful advice, if you need to boil about 500g/ml of water, fill it up to a little under the 2nd ridge on the inside, it should be just a little over 500g, giving you some buffer in case if you leave it on boil for a little too long, or if you just want to pour a bit extra.

The only minor gripe I have with it, is that its a little hard to tell when the water is at a rolling boil at times unless you are right next to the kettle. Nothing whistles, there are no thermometers, and its not automatic, so you have to listen for the rumbling of the water within and watch for the steam that comes out from the vent in the lid.
author: Elc
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 25 de enero de 2023

title: Looks fragile but is so so sturdy.
body:
This kettle is a lesson in â€˜donâ€™t judge a book by its coverâ€™

I got it last week and was worried that Iâ€™ll have to use a tawa below it on a gas or it might get ruined. Thought Japanese engineering didnâ€™t take Indian gas stoves into account. But boy was I wrong.

Been using this on high flame on a gas stove to make my v60 brews and forget staining ot becoming black where the flame hits, this one doesnâ€™t even make the weird noises that an average Indian steel utensil that is this thin makes.

Even though it looks delicate (which it ie if you throw it around), the stainless steel used here is of supreme quality.
And pours so, so beautifully.
Worry the price? Maybe not. But if youâ€™re like me and want a proper pouring kettle, go for it. You wonâ€™t regret it.

Just make sure the handle and the flame donâ€™t touch each other ever since the handle is plastic (which doesnâ€™t heat up thansk to the angle).

body: Die Aufgusskanne habe ich zusammen mit dem HARIO Coffee Dripper, den dazugehÃ¶rigen FiltertÃ¼ten und der Glaskanne Range Server meinem Mann zu Weihnachten geschenkt. Ist super angekommen und seitdem tÃ¤glich im Gebrauch. Die Aufgusskanne aus Edelstahl sieht nicht nur wunderschÃ¶n aus, sondern ist auch extrem leicht. Der schwarze Griff aus Kunststoff liegt gut in der Hand, auch wenn die Kanne gefÃ¼llt ist. Von der GrÃ¶ÃŸe her passt sie exakt auf die kleinste Platte unseres Cerankochfeldes. Laut Hersteller ist sie auf allen WÃ¤rmequellen verwendbar. Der geschwungene Ausguss (Schwanenhals) ermÃ¶glicht ein punktgenaues und mengendosiertes AufgieÃŸen. So lÃ¤sst sich Kaffeegenuss stilvoll zelebrieren. Nach Gebrauch wird die Kanne stets von innen getrocknet - ich hoffe nicht, dass sie wie ich in einer anderen Rezension gelesen habe, anfÃ¤ngt zu rosten. title: Brilliant drip kettle - stop asking and buy
body:
I did a whopping amount of googling before buying one of these. I was sceptical that I needed one but I wanted to do coffee right. It's not that you need one to make a coffee, because you don't. But when you do make a coffee with this it feels like much more of an occasion, which rightly or wrongly is what I enjoy about making a coffee with a Chemex and this.

Yes the flow is easy to control and you can basically wet any grain of coffee at will, but filling it with boiling water, pouring like you know what you are doing and drying it at the end is all apart of my routine now and I love it. I empty it and shove a towel in and about to dry it each time and I've never seen rust or any issues. I do that whilst the Chemex is dripping out.

It also looks great on the shelf. So stop worrying and if you want the experience go ahead. Good luck!

title: Well Made & Well Designed
body:
Great build quality and design, offers fantastic control for your pour-over coffee. A word of advice: I highly recommend purchasing this larger size kettle over the smaller one. They state in the manual and on the box that you should not fill this kettle more than half-way, otherwise (as another reviewer has posted) the water will boil over. Isn't an issue for me since I'm not making more than 2 cups of coffee at a time. If I need more water in one batch I'll boil it in another kettle first then transfer into this kettle.

I highly suggest filtering your water before boiling so you never have to descale this kettle. It's too pretty to even consider getting to that point :)

title: This kettle exceeded my expections
body:
I recently got into pour over coffee. I was carefully considering all the pieces involved and how much it was going to cost me. When I was going to buy the coffee maker, I ended up buying the Chemex 6-cup figuring if I was going to spend money for this endeavor, I was going to get the best. When I was looking to buy a goose neck kettle for my pour over coffee, I considered many options out there and tried to find a deal on a less expensive kettle than the Hario V60. In the end, I went with the same thought: might as well get the best.

When I took it out of the box, it seemed somewhat light and I thought to myself, "can I really boil water with this?" To my surprise, it feels real sturdy when using it. The water boils quickly and evenly and it is a pleasure to use. It doesn't feel cheap. I figured pay more now for something that will last me a long time.

I am pleased with this purchase and glad I bought it. It is more expensive than other goose neck kettles, but it's high quality and you really can't go wrong, especially if it's something I'm going to be using every day.
author: Zech 4_6
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 2 de enero de 2021

title: GREAT pour-over kettle - it looks good, it functions great, and it's a nice balance of build-quality/good design + affordability
body:
This is my second purchase of the Hario V60 Kettle. It is an awesome product and it makes an incredible gift.

This type of kettle is a special-use product and it has a few different names. I have heard "long-neck", "goose neck", "drip", and "pour over" kettle. More or less, this is a smaller & lightweight kettle (about 4 cups capacity but performance is best when you are closer to a max of 3-3.5 cups) and it is made for control. By control I mean that it pours slowly, and in a predictable manner to allow the user to have maximum control over how much water they pour. For usage of certain brew products (such as the Hario Drip Coffee maker, the Chemex, or the AeroPress, this control is hugely beneficial. For when you are making a cup of tea or two for yourself, this is also hugely beneficial. With this increased control, the sort of pour-over kettle also greatly reduces messes, and arguably reduces the chance of accidents leading to burns.

As you can see by the listing, the capacity of this is smaller (27 ounces max) because the products this is made primarily for have relatively low capacities (and many are frequently used for preparing a single-serving.) The implication is that this V60 (and most pour-over kettles) are not very suitable to brew a large quantity of a hot drink. My solution to this is a $13 giant kettle for the rare occasions I am making a large quantity of tea that exceeds the capacity of my Hario V60.

Being stainless steel, this product has a few functional advantages:
--It works with gas, electric, induction, and even open-range sources of heat
--It does NOT react to the boiling water (so the drink you are preparing will not have any off-taste that comes from the brewing tools)
--It is easy to clean
--It is highly heat-resistant & durable (the pour spout has been beefed up so that it holds up to long-term usage)
--It is lightweight, making it easy to maneuver and therefore increasing control

The method I use most to make coffee is with the Chemex (I also brew tea in it). Being a borosilicate glass, I like this because it has absolutely no effect on flavor and I find that many other brewing methods result in the flavor of coffee or tea being modified due to the materials that the brewing apparatus is made from (Hario's own V60 Drip Brew is like the Chemex as it does not impact the flavor...and also like the Chemex, it uses much thicker/denser filters to achieve coffee of notable purity and good taste.) Some kettles have surfaces that can react with boiling water and modify the flavor. While I like borosilicate for things not going on the stove, I prefer a metal kettle for something constantly seeing high-heat and temp jumps. So I purchased a Hario V60 Kettle and since then it has been a great companion.

The build quality of this is very good. While the Hario is more expensive than many other kettles, it is a quality piece. The pour spout is STRONG and can withstand the beating that a daily-use kettle will see. The handles have good ergos, are comfortable, and have reasonably good heat resistance. The lid design is also excellent in that it does not become tighter/looser as temperature changes (something another kettle I have does terribly) and the handle on the lid makes it easy to remove without making contact with the metal surfaces. While this product does not whistle, it does have three top vent holes that visibly release steam when the water is boiling, and it is very visibly noticeable (like 2-3+ feet high at a full-boil). The lid should always be placed on the unit in a way in which these three holes are furthest AWAY from the handle (to prevent steam burns.)

There is only one possible downside (other than price) which is that this kettle is intended to ONLY boil water. It is not the best candidate for brewing coffee or tea directly in (I highly recommend brewing inside a borosilicate or ceramic pitcher/cup/jar because of how borosilicate is non-reactive regardless of temp or pH.) However, I look at this as being more by-design than a downside...not to mention how this sort of kettle is very impractical to brew directly in.

The V60 kettle is quickly becoming an industry standard for this kind of pour-over kettle. It's popular in the home setting; it's popular with coffee houses for professional usage, and it's not hard to see why: the Hario V60 Kettle is well-made to a point in which it can withstand years of constant usage, it performs exactly how this sort of [very useful] kettle should function, and it is reasonably-priced for this type of product. So I highly recommend the Hario V60 Kettle.

I have bought a number of Hario products over the years and all are made with care and quality. This kettle is no exception. I bought the kettle for it's precision spout, to use while making filter coffee. I works perfectly on my induction cooker and brings the water to the boil quickly. The small spout is perfect for a precise pour.
The only drawback to this product is that the actual operational volume of the kettle is 0.8 Litre. If you were to fill it any more, you would risk spillage when boiling. But I believe this would be true to all kettles of this type.

date: Revisado en Reino Unido el 19 de febrero de 2016

title: Good if you need accurate pours to make coffee, but be careful! This isn't for everyone.
body:
This is a nice looking kettle that has some advantages and disadvantages. I purchased this to use with my Chemex, so that I would have more accurate pours (to avoid washing the grinds down the sides of the filter, and keep the water poured in the center). For that, I would give this product 5 stars, if it were not for some of it's other less-than-ideal qualities. Some background: I use a chemex coffee maker every morning, and grind my coffee beans right before I brew it. I weigh out my coffee (usuallly 1.5 oz) and then add an appropriate amount of water (24 fl. oz. by weight). I've been using this coffee maker every day for a month. Here's what I've noticed:

Particularly annoying is the fact that this does not whistle when the water boils. I've never had a kettle that didn't do that (except for electric kettles which simply shut off). Furthermore, there are 3 holes on top of the lid where steam blows out. In order to check to see if the water is boiling, you need to remove the lid. As a result, you're quite likely to burn your hand from the steam jetting out of the lid's holes if you're not careful. I've also noticed that because the base isn't so wide, it takes a much longer time to bring water to a boil than my wife's electric kettle. Also, 1.2 liters isn't as much water as you might think, because you'll not fill it to the top. So, in summary:

Pros:
> Attractive
> Gooseneck allows very accurate pours, which is why I purchased this. Must-have if you use a chemex.

Cons:
> Does not whistle when water boils
> Three holes on top of lid will scald your hand if you're not careful!!
> Takes a while to bring water to a boil
> Once you've made your coffee, you may not have water left over for a cup of tea, you'll need to boil water again. Obviously, this depends on how much coffee you make, but I make a 24 fl. oz. pot every morning (I weigh it).

So I would recommend this to anyone who uses a chemex or similar pour-over coffee brewing method and needs a very accurate pour from their kettle. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone else.

title: Handle falls off... extremely dangerous
body: Iâ€™ve purchased quite a few of these kettles for our coffee shop (and one for my home as well), and Iâ€™ve been let down a number of times. While the feel and pour of the kettle is nice, the handle is held on by only a few small welding dots which overtime fail (every single kettle has lost its handle within a matter of 3-5 months). The first couple of times it happened we caught it while the kettle was empty. Unfortunately, the last time it happened, the kettle was full of hot water which came crashing down all over my leg. I suffered considerable second degree burns on my leg as a result. Lesson learned... this kettle is not meant for daily use in a shop setting (or daily use in a home setting for that matter). If youâ€™re handle feels loose STOP using it immediately. Cheaply constructed, not durable and DANGEROUS! Will not be purchasing this item again.

body: Purchased this kettle August 2019, so after almost a year of good use, I am very disappointed with the quality. I purchased the product despite many reviews mentioning this item was not made in Japan and bad comments on the quality. But I would not purchase this product again. The worst part is that it does not hold the temperature for long. I've had cheap kettles that maintain the temperature for more than 30 mins easily but this one did not even hold for 10-15 mins. This kettle is overpriced and the basic functionality of temperature control is horrible. The exterior quickly got yellow rust/mold stains, despite taking good care of it and scrubbing it carefully. I would not recommend purchasing this product because the material is cheap, does not hold heat, and gets stained easily. Very dissapointed!

After only 2 days of light use the kettle changed color and the bottom seem to be completely burned (see pictures). The interior of the kettle looks also burned and turned black in some areas so now I'm afraid to use it so I'm returning it right now.
From other reviews I learned now that some of these kettles are made in Japan and some made in China and I found that mine is made in China so I called my friend that recommend it to me and learn that his was made in Japan and he hasn't experienced the same problem.

title: This Is Not What It Seems.
body:
Do not be deceived.

While this is a fairly nice gooseneck kettle for pour-over coffee and tea, it is falsely advertised as a product from Japan. I bought it under the assumption that it was in fact Japanese, however this is not the case. I later looked at the box again after reading that there was a possibility a chance that I could've gotten one from China, instead of Japan. And as luck would have it, I did have a "Made in China" kettle.

So, not only did I not get what I paid for, but they also lied straight to my face.

I've heard it said that experience is not the best teacher. Other people's experience is the best teacher. Please learn from my experience and do not buy this if you want a kettle that is actually Japanese.

title: Not what I was looking for
body:
So I probably was wanting a hybrid. Something between the standard tea kettle and this thing.

I love the spout being at the bottom of the kettle, and its size, it makes for easy and precise pouring.

However, it's not very big (1.2L) which is alright. However, I bought this to serve my 10cup Chemex which it can't do but could do a half portion (5cups). However, even following the suggested fill line of this kettle, the water would boil over, it wouldn't whistle, and it just made a mess. I know you shouldn't leave the room while boiling water, but this thing surprises you while your working on something else in the kitchen! It just starts boiling over. You hear the roar of boiling water but that doesn't always get your attention. Plus, I just like the good ol' whistle!

I sent this product back after a week.

title: Fake Hario Kettle
body:
Where do I start. I absolutely love the Hario kettle. I have had many prior to this one and have bought many for friends and family.

1. This kettle rusted on the inside. How? I am not sure and I am surely dissapointed. This is what first tipped me to think this was a fake.
2. I compared this one to my old Hario kettle and surely enough, completely different in subtle ways (spout shape between the two was different).

I will not be purchasing from this seller again and will now only purchase from the website or coffee shops where I know it's the real deal.
author: Alexandria Ward
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 3 de febrero de 2016

title: Handle broke off after one month of standard use
body:
I have had this kettle for about a month and really liked it - until today. I have used it daily to make coffee (seemed like pretty standard use to me) and then when I went to pick it up off of the stove the handle just broke off. Seems like it should last a bit longer....

I have reached out to the Hario customer service team and will update my review if I hear back, but for now it just seems like the low cost isn't that great of a value if it just breaks after a month of use!
author: M Schneider
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 2 de diciembre de 2016

title: Different than last Hario V60
body: I was replacing an old kettle with a new one. But the new one was slightly different. For one thing, boiling water didnâ€™t rattle the lid (like on the old one) so you canâ€™t tell if your waterâ€™s boiling. Useless.
author: Brian Boyle
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 16 de septiembre de 2022

title: Very poor spout design.
body: This kettle is awful! I bought it because it was recommended to use with the Hario pour-over method of coffee. However, it is a terrible design. Because of the low placement of the spout, the second the water starts to boil it spurts out everywhere! You have to catch it right before it boils. Not only is this dangerous, it makes a total mess. Also, the exterior of the pot has completely discolored and tarnished in just two months of using it. I would return it if I could but I waited too long. Instead I will have to throw it in the recycling bin.Total waste of money!
author: Likes To Cook_44
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 23 de octubre de 2015

title: Not for use with German water
body: My last kettle stainless steel kettle lasted without issue for eight years, but when we moved to Germany, it began to show signs of wear, including minor rust. I ordered a new one, and within weeks, rust appeared. It seems Germanyâ€™s water is problematic. We bought the coffee pot cleaner from the grocery store and have used only filtered water since we cleaned it, but rust remains. I donâ€™t recommend purchasing this and using it in Germany,
author: Amanda
date: Revisado en Alemania el 8 de marzo de 2021

title: Rust after 2 months, thanks Amazon
body: I read the reviews warning of rust problems before purchasing. I choose to buy direct from Amazon assuming I would get an authentic, made in Japan, product that way. Only after noticing this rust problem did I go back to the listing and notice that it is indeed made in China. I've used this kettle less then 20 times.The rust is developing along the bottom interior seem. Very disappointed in Amazon's choice to sell inauthentic product. I will be sure to confirm that my replacement kettle is made in Japan. Other then the rust, the kettle functions very good.
author: J Davis
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de febrero de 2017

title: Absolute junk
body: No idea how this got a good rating. Its a piece of junk. Boils over, is incredibly hot to the touch and is starting to rust after less than 2 months. Garbage and a complete waste of money
author: Pamela J Keith
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 29 de abril de 2022

title: Seems like itâ€™s not an actual Hario Kettle
body: Like others mentioned made in China not Japan. My original one says made in Japan on the bottom and this one does not. See photos for proof of where it says itâ€™s made. Also arrived with a completely broken handle. Also in photos. Not sure whatâ€™s going on as I ordered from the â€œHario Amazon storeâ€

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 22 de marzo de 2021

title: I ordered this specifically to avoid buying a tea kettle ...
body: I ordered this specifically to avoid buying a tea kettle that was made in China (I have nothing against China, but I do have a problem with lax health and safety standards when it comes to something I'll be putting water in to drink). Unfortunately when it arrived it was stamped "Made in China" on both the box and the kettle itself. I returned it and went to Williams and Sonoma to buy one that was stamped "Made in Japan". Cost me a little more money, but worth it. Hopefully the one from Williams and Sonoma isn't lying!
author: Kimchi Schnitzel
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 12 de febrero de 2015

title: Too many Hario poor quality reviews; take them seriously
body:
We're used to buying 'Japan' with an assumption of quality control. I guess these days are quickly closing. Read the reviews. Ours didn't last two minutes out of the box .... the top of the lid broke off.

It's easy to see why .... only one of the 3 tiny pegs were connected. Poor manufacturing (box and product from China). We'll watch for rust next ... we re-superglued the top. I'm not even sure it's Hario (ignoring the labeling) ... the english translation was pretty rough.
author: Denise
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 5 de noviembre de 2015

title: defective knob on lid again
body:
I can't comment on how well this kettle works, because I've never reached that stage. This is the second Hario Buono kettle I've purchased from Amazon, and both had defective knobs on the lid. Both had a rough scraped area on the edge of the black plastic knob. At this price, I think the kettle should be in better condition straight out of the box. Not thrilled at having to go through the return process again.
The other reviews are all so positive, and I love my coffee soooo much, that I will probably try this kettle again--but not from Amazon.
author: Lulu Reading
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 1 de diciembre de 2011

title: BEWARE - MADE IN CHINA
body:
I thought Hario is made in Japan!? This is made in China! I have washed it with soap and water numerous times, boiled 10 kettles of water through it, yet it still produces a horrible metallic after taste! For hours after drinking a coffee I feel like I have coins in my mouth. Returning for refund. Do not be fooled, real Hario's are made in Japan!

UPDATE: I bought a V60 locally that is made in Japan, zero after taste! Buyer beware!
author: TheLemon
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 21 de octubre de 2016

title: Disappointed
body: Just opened my package and this is what was inside. Rusted or tarnished drip kettle. Looks like it was used and returned.

body: Really terrible that this product has so many stars. I imagine they were originally selling the Made in Japan version to get the good reviews and then switched over once they could coast on their reviews. This made in china version is lighter, not as well made, prone to rusting, and other serious problems. Do yourself a favor and avoid this product until they switch back to supplying the version made in Japan.

title: Kein Edelstahl Korpus
body: Der Artikel wird beschrieben, dass jener aus Edelstahl sei. Meiner Meinung nach ist es leider kein Edelstahl, da reines Edelstahl nicht magnetisch ist. Der Kesselboden muss magnetisch sein, da er Induktionsherd geeignet sein sollte, das habe ich allerdings nicht getestet. Leider stellte ich am restlichen Korpus magnetische Anziehung fest, was das ganze auf maximal rosttrÃ¤gen Stahl reduziert, das heiÃŸt Rostbildung bei Feuchtigkeit ist definitiv nicht auszuschlieÃŸen. Ich versuche den Artikel zurÃ¼ck zu senden.

title: Leaking after 4 years of occasional use
body: Iâ€™ve had the gooseneck kettle for 4 years now. It was great but recently the bottom of the kettle started leaking. Quality isnâ€™t great.

date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 1 de marzo de 2021

title: Not Worth IT & Miss Leading!!!
body:
I bought this Hario V60 Kettle and after 39 days of using it the inside seam has RUST. I want to return it and get a different kettle however the site only allows a return on 30 days.
Also, on details/description it reads Made in Japan. On the packaging and underneath the kettle its made in China.
NOT happy with this Hario V60 Gooseneck!!!
author: sharkbait
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 12 de marzo de 2019

title: Terrible discoloration and handle gets too hot
body: I originally loved the look of this teapot however, I have only had it since January and after daily use, it is terribly discolored (rusted looking all over ) despite my efforts to clean it and the handle gets extremely hot when pouring the water. I am disappointed with this product. I am a daily tea drinker and am now planning to shop for a new tea kettle.
author: Kara Lammes
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 19 de octubre de 2018

title: DANGEROUS. Lid comes off. Kettle shakes. Handle is too hot.
body: DANGEROUS and poorly designed. The lid comes off when pouring. The lid comes off when the water inside is boiling-- loud enough that it is rattling! The entire kettle jostles side to side when the water starts to boil. The manual warns that the handle can become too hot-- so you should use an oven mitt with this product. Very worried about the damage this could do to my family or my kitchen.
author: Olive Tree
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 2 de noviembre de 2014

title: Great for Boiling and pouring, But hard black plastic will break in less then a year
body: I loved this Hario, great for pour overs. I need to give it 1 star since the handle sheared off in less than a year. Unsure if mine was a defect, but it did not last nearly as long as expected. I reached out to Hario via email twice (and received confirmation email was received by them), but they never responded back to me with any customer service.
author: Sam Steffen
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 28 de febrero de 2017

title: SHOOTS BOILING HOT WATER 1FT INTO THE AIR
body: This kettle worked for almost a year until recently. It began shooting a stream of boiling water in the last few weeks. It floods a counter and has the risk of severely injuring anyone near it. Not sure what causes the issue, going to attempt to contact the company about getting a replacement or refund.
author: John Masuga
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 7 de noviembre de 2019

title: It arrived in good condition but bottom stamped "made in China" to our ...
body: Beware. We ordered as stainless steel and made in Japan. It arrived in good condition but bottom stamped "made in China" to our surprise. We decided to go ahead and keep it......rusted in two months!!! Not stainless steel. Of course, past the time to return. We may use as a planter but likely will just recycle. We bought the real Hario V60 from William Sonoma on line, same price. Beware.
author: Charles R. Neal, Jr. MD
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 5 de diciembre de 2015

title: Not a good one.
body: One of the main reasons I bought this kettle was due to the fact that it wouldn't rust. Well, the product is poorly manufactured because it did rust in the first 30 days of use, even when I made sure to leave no standing water in the kettle and let it dry thoroughly. I feel jipped that I cannot return it and get my money back...
author: Amazon Customer
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 25 de octubre de 2015

title: stainless steel?
body: After cooking with it for almost 2 years, the bottom of the kettle started to rust? I guess this is a normal steel with a coating. Stainless steal is, when it is a good steel with higher nickel content not magnetic - but this one is. Would not recommend to buy!

title: Rust inside after a short while
body: The kettle started rusting inside after 1-2 months of use, first tiny spots that could be brushed away, but now after 5 months the rust is definite and also leaves a metal taste to the water.

title: Chinese junk don't be fooled
body:
Don't waste your money on this Chinese imposter. This is something made specifically to satisfy the mass unsuspecting market amazon has cultivated. The metal is very thin and can dent with finger pressure. The plastic also appears to have some oily residue on it and mine looked scuffed right out of the box.

Go to williams and sonoma and they will price match amazon's price for the japanese made version of this kettle.

title: I'm sad because it's cute and worked well for pour-over coffee
body: I've only had this kettle for two months and it's seriously rusted already. It's giving off a noxious chemical smell when the water is heated. I'm sad because it's cute and worked well for pour-over coffee. But I am scared to use it now, so it will be going in the garbage. :(

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 11 de diciembre de 2015

title: Rusted!
body: I purchased this kettle in 2014, and now , 2 years later, it's rusting inside. I'm very disappointed, as I liked this pot. I bought it because it was supposed to be stainless steel and therefore wouldn't rust. Left wondering what is IS made of...and feeling quite crabby.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 19 de octubre de 2016

title: Buyer beware
body:
The handle is glued to the kettle, not welded.
When glue gets hot it melts.

The handle came of this after boiling as I was pouring. Boiling water hit my legs and narrowly missed my son who was playing on the kitchen floor.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 16 de diciembre de 2016

title: Unless you like the taste of rust in your coffee, don't buy this product
body: This thing is a TRAIN WRECK to keep clean. I use filtered water exclusively and I still get rust/brown spots that appear after just a few uses. Hario also makes it impossible to find any sort of article online with how to keep this kettle clean.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 29 de septiembre de 2016

title: Rust rust rust
body:
Rust rust rust rust rust rust.
This is not an opinion.
The inside bottom where the 2 pieces of metal meet:rust.
You can buy if you want, go for it.
But mine rusted.
Less than 3 weeks.
5 stars on their return!

title: Aus guten GrÃ¼nden eher nicht zu empfehen...
body:
Auf der Suche nach einem vernÃ¼nftigen Wasserkessel bin ich auf dieses Schicke Exemplar der Hario-Serie fÃ¼r KaffeegenieÃŸer gestoÃŸen. Aus der Ferne wirkte alles gut und so landete das Produkt gleich mal auf der Wunschliste. Einige Tage und Recherchen spÃ¤ter stand der Kaufentschluss fest. Ãœberzeugend waren vorallem die Aussagen zur Handhabung, QualitÃ¤t und zur Pflegeleichtigkeit. Hier nun meine mÃ¶glichst objektiv gehaltenen GrÃ¼nde dafÃ¼r, warum die RealitÃ¤t oftmals eine andere ist. ZunÃ¤chst einmal zu den beiden wohlwollenden Sternchen.

- Liegt gut in der Hand und sieht recht schick aus
- Sehr gutes Ausflussverhalten (keine Kleckereien) und optimales Dosieren der Wassermenge mÃ¶glich

Das war es dann aber auch schon. Und wahrscheinlich bieten das auch gÃ¼nstigere Produkte. Und da wÃ¤ren wir auch schon beim grÃ¶ÃŸten Problem: das Preis-/Leistungs VerhÃ¤ltnis. Das Material wirkt Ã¤uÃŸerst billig, auchwenn es sich um relativ gut verarbeitetes Edelstahlt handelt. Die NÃ¤hte scheinen mir recht verletzlich und rostanfÃ¤llig. TatsÃ¤chlich hatte die Kanne bereits Rost angesetzt und das als Neuware! Und zwar an der Innenseite der Stelle wo Halterung und Wand verschweisst oder was auch immer sind. Es sollte also nicht lange dauern, bis der Rest auch zu rosten beginnt, auch wenn man es furztrocken wischt. Denn irgendwo bleibt immer etwas Wasser zurÃ¼ck, was mich zur Reinigung bringt. Eine MÃ¤nnerhand passt nur bedingt in das Loch um eben den Innenteil grundlich trocken zu legen. Und dabei habe ich recht kleine HÃ¤nde. DarÃ¼ber hinaus wird die FÃ¼llmenge bei Amazon zunÃ¤chst mit 1,2 Litern angegeben. Auch bei anderen Anbietern steht diese Angabe. Und selbst auf der Verpackung wird damit geworben. Der Hersteller weist in der Beschreibung aber deutlich darauf hin das GefÃ¤ÃŸ mit nicht mehr als 800ml zu befÃ¼llen. Auch Amazon weist darauf hin, dass es wohl weniger sein werden als die 1,2l. Allerdings empfinde ich das als irrefÃ¼hrend. SchlieÃŸlich der Preis. Aktuell ist die Kanne bei Amazon fÃ¼r rund 40 Taler zu haben. Eigentlich sollte sie 60 kosten. Andere Anbieter gehen sogar auf Ã¼ber 80. Nach dem Gesamteindruck, den die Kanne auf mich macht, eine absolute Frechheit. Wahrscheinlich verhÃ¤lt es sich in Deutschland mit den japanische rodukten genauso wie in Japan mit den deutschen. Schlagen wir mal 300% drauf, denn es kommt ja aus Japan oder eben Deutschland. Diese Erfahrung habe ich bereits mehrfach machen mÃ¼ssen und dann entweder importiert oder den Kauf ganz gelassen. Und bei diesem Produkt scheint es mir nicht anders zu sein. Ich wage zu bezweiefeln, dass die Kanne in Japan umgerechnet zwischen 40 und 80 Euro kosten soll. Ich tippe mal auf hÃ¶chstens 30. Und selbst das wÃ¤re noch das zenhfache der Materialkosten. Ja, es regt mich auf...

Die Ware geht zurÃ¼ck und einmal mehr darf ich auf die RÃ¼cknahmekullanz Amazons hoffen... Und derweil habe ich auch eine Alternative entdeckt, die, wie eingangs erwÃ¤hnt, alle positiven Merkmale erfÃ¼llt und darÃ¼ber hinaus auch die negativen Aspekte ins Gegenteil umkehrt. In diesem Sinne, Aussehen ist nicht alles!
author: Dooly
date: Revisado en Alemania el 17 de octubre de 2015

title: Mit eingebauter Schwachstelle
body: Eigentlich bin ich mit der Funktion der Kanne sehr zufrieden. Das AusgieÃŸen funktioniert einwandfrei und wohl dosiert. Leider ist jetzt auch schon die zweite Kanne nach knapp zwei Jahren undicht. Und das wieder an gleicher Stelle. Der Griff ist mit zwei LÃ¶tstellen an der recht dÃ¼nnwandigen Kanne befestigt. Und genau dort tritt jetzt schon wieder Wasser aus. Da ich den gleichen Mangel auch schon mit meiner ersten Kanne hatte gehe ich von einem Konstruktionsfehler aus. Ich finde es mehr als Ã¤rgerlich, alle zwei Jahre eine neue Kanne kaufen zu mÃ¼ssen, welche ansonsten noch vollkommen in Ordnung ist.
author: Andre M.
date: Revisado en Alemania el 10 de abril de 2023

title: Not good for induction
body: I have a Miele induction stove and this kettle does not really work on it, yes it heats up, but it starts vibrating like crazy and makes a rather unpleasant boomy sound. Dont buy if you intend to use a induction stove
author: Thomas Tammann
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de junio de 2023

title: The thing I dont like about this product is that the kettle does not ...
body:
The thing I dont like about this product is that the kettle does not whistle when the water is boiling so you really have to keep an eye on it. If the water level inside the kettle isnt very high, then a subtle steam will come through the holes that you have to make sure you look for. If the water level inside the kettle is higher, then you can expect the water to come up through the spout and spill hot water all over your stove top. Due to this, you really cant put much water inside the kettle. I use this to heat water for my pour-over coffee carafe, but often end up having to heat two rounds of water to get the volume of water desired to make my daily coffee. So rather than thinking of this kettle as 1.2 L, I would think of it as roughly 2/3 the size.

I really like the design of the kettle! It is sleek looking and doesnt take up much room at all. But I would certainly sacrifice this for a better working kettle that whistles and doesn't spill over.
author: Janessa
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 29 de abril de 2016

title: Not made in Japan (bought from Amazon.ca)
body:
Bought it from Amazon.ca, where the description initially mentionned it was made in Japan. When I received the item, it said it was made in China and the description seemed to have been corrected accordingly since. This was a huge disappointment for me, so instead, I bought it from Amazon Japan amd got the one made in Japan.

The difference in quality between the two was distinctive. The China made one was way more flimsy, in thinner metal and the angle of the handle abd pout were different from the one made in Japan.

If you are looking for the one made in Japan, don't bother buying from Amazon.ca; go on the Japanese Amazon instead. It was about the same price, shipping included, and it arrived in 2-3 days.
author: Laurence
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 9 de julio de 2018

title: Rusts with normal use
body: Rusts with normal use, rust spots that do not come out! I thought this was made of stainless steel and not suppose to rust? In hindsight should have checked the warranty policy before purchase.
author: CP
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 21 de marzo de 2022

title: Meh.
body: Not a huge fan: on one side, the special drip coffee pouring part doesn't seem absolutely necessary (my previous kettle didn't have one and worked fine just the same), plus, there doesn't seem to be a max level sign inside but if you do fill the kettle (not even to the rim, I still leave an inch or so), the boiling water will actually come out of the pouring thing (that is not great at all, it could cause accidents), plus the whole thing is actually not cabinet enoughl to fill a 6c Chemex (my bad, I should have done the match, still) so while you're still in the process of making coffee you need to boil some more water. Bottom line: this kettle is a pain.
author: sigi
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 15 de marzo de 2017

title: Lost its shine quickly
body: I've owned this kettle for less than a month before it tarnished. It developed these dark brown spots, and the entire kettle had gotten darker as well. The inside of the kettle has gotten more blue as time has gone on. The water however tastes fine. There is no material falling into my cup and there's no reason I'd stop using it. I love using it for my Hario v60, it's great for slow, controlled pouring. The plastic on the handle is in perfect condition, and the plastic on top is fine too. Disappointed considering the quality of the Hario v60 and the Skerton grinder is so high.
author: Alex K
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 30 de septiembre de 2017

title: Poor quality, handle broke off the lid
body:
After just a few uses the handle on the lid broke off. I've glued it back on using Gorilla glue and it appears to be holding up. Disappointed that what is meant to be a top make broke like this. Although from reading other reviews they are now made in China and the quality is not what it used to be.
If the handle comes off again I will return it.
author: NeoGee
date: Revisado en Reino Unido el 11 de octubre de 2020

author: Y
date: Revisado en JapÃ³n el 22 de enero de 2023

title: received an unlabeled, likely China made version; inaccurate PD
body: Ordered from Amazon after seeing reviews that they sold the Japanese made 1.2L kettle and it is described as the country of origin in their Product Description. However, I received a kettle that was unlabeled on the steel bottom and the box was labeled Made in China. The construction and weight of materials is shotty and you can clearly see the differences. I also think it's pretty sketchy not to label the physical product with it's country of origin, even if it has to be China. The pot works, but won't last with the quality it has vs what it should be.
author: courtalones
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 20 de febrero de 2017

title: If you don't keep it dry, it rusts.
body: The instructions say that this kettle needs to be dried out between uses and I know why. It rusts. It's really strange to me that a stainless steel kettle can't have water sit inside it indefinitely, but that's the case with this one. My personal theory is that it's a manufacturing defect that's too expensive to rectify, so they just tell the customer to try to keep it dry. I will say, though, that the customer service rep was friendly and I was very appreciative that they offered me a replacement kettle free of charge. I didn't dry out the kettle between uses though, so this one has rusted as well. I like everything else about this product, but the rust is a fatal flaw for me. So I can't recommend it. I do hope they figure out a way to fix it going forward.
author: W. Guppy
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 2 de mayo de 2014

title: Do not buy if it's made in China.
body:
I bought this kettle last year (made in Japan), and it had been working great for me. Unfortunately it was damaged and I needed to get a new one.

I just bought another one (made in China), and there is a significant difference for the worse. After boiling filtered water in this new kettle, there is a very heavy metallic taste. I'll continue using it for a little while to see if it dissipates, but in my experience it does not go away very easily.

title: I Loved the way it Looks
body:
I love the looks of this kettle and the way it pours. It's hard to explain but it gives you so much control over where and how much you are pouring. It just feels right when you lift it.
The problem is that it was leaking where the spout joined the kettle. Even though it costs more than other kettles it would have been worth it because it looks and feels so good, but not with a flaw. I sent it back. I'm still kind of sad about it.
Amazon is so good about returns. They provide the label and make it so easy.
author: Judi J.
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 15 de diciembre de 2011

date: Revisado en JapÃ³n el 21 de diciembre de 2022

title: Functional but likely too flimsy
body: I a typical coffee obsessive, (probably overly)concerned with brewing technique. I don't make pour-over coffee often, but when I did, I wanted to be able to control the flow of hot water onto the grounds. This kettle is ideally designed to do that, with it's long, thin spout than can be positioned immediately over the coffee. I don't use it often, in fact, I think I had used it less than ten times before it sprung a leak from its base plate, inundating the burner while it was heating the water. Now I'm waiting to see if Hario will do something about that. What they should do is use a heavier gauge stainless steel.
author: Gerard Balsley
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 13 de agosto de 2011

title: It is great for pour over coffee and is just the right ...
body:
I love(d) this kettle. It is great for pour over coffee and is just the right size for my chemex. Had I made this review within 2 months of owning it, it would be a 5 star review. That said, after 18 months of owning it, aesthetically, it has not held up well.

It's gone from looking gorgeous to looking blemished, dingy, and rusted. I wash and hand dry after every use. I think the metal doesn't take well to being used on a gas range.
author: Manu Narayan
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 31 de mayo de 2016

title: updated review. After one year this kettle has started to rust...badly...around the bottom.
body:
This is a great little kettle with enough water for 4 small coffees, heats up quickly and pours with precision.
HOWEVER...the biggest drawback is that this kettle does not "sing". There have been many times I forget I put it on to boil...and caught myself with only a little water left.
author: Lara Johnson
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 17 de abril de 2016

title: disappointing and elegant
body:
At $36 (plus tax,etc) this should have been great. Yes, it was least expensive listing for that specific piece on Amazon, but that's why we shop Amazon. Has lots of great reviews.
Handsome and perfect for it's stated purpose. Description states it can be used on a gas range.
And it was for a while, but started leaking after two months of daily use. To the point it was deemed dangerous to use. My daughter has ordered another brand and we'll hope for the best.
author: J. crawford
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 29 de diciembre de 2015

title: Quality changed...
body:
I had one that was made in Japan but gave it to my parent in law. Ordered this and was surprised to the quality difference between the two (especially the plastic handle and brush metal).

Although it pour fine but I returned it due to the change of quality.
author: jmonkey
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 11 de mayo de 2017

title: China not Japan
body:
This kettle is made in China and it says so on the bottom, not Japan as the seller alleges. If you were thinking this is a Japanese product this is not the one!

After using this kettle daily for 4 months it is beginning to rust on the inside around the entire bottom seam. Apparently it is a low quality of stainless steel or they used some other material for the bottom weld. I do not recommend this kettle unless you get the one actually made in japan which this is not.
author: GroovyD
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 31 de diciembre de 2014

title: But I like it and it serves well
body: It's small, my regular burner needs to be turned down so the handle doesn't get burned or melted. Remember to take it off the burner before the water starts spouting out. If you only need a little water (like a cup of tea) it doesn't emit a whistle. But I like it and it serves well. But most tea kettles don't crap out in the first year, so we'll see.
author: Lisa R.
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 8 de diciembre de 2016

title: Stains the stainless
body: I bought this and got the made in Japan product because I made sure with the seller where it is made. After few weeks of using this, the outside of the stainless starts to have stains that does not come off with detergent like the Hario instructed. It is so hassle for me to return but most likely I have to return this...
author: Ji Hye Choi
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 13 de mayo de 2017

title: Made in China
body: This kettle is made in China, not Japan. It's lightweight and very tinny. Also, there is no grip to the lidâ€”so loose it will fall off when pouring. I don't think the quality of this kettle merits the price. Very disappointed.
author: ID
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 21 de octubre de 2016

title: Handle gets hot!
body:
Looks nice on stove but you need a pot holder while pouring as the handle gets hot as heck!
Not worth the money
author: Diamond Girl
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 13 de octubre de 2021

title: Made in China - returned
body: My current one is great product made in Japan. I decided to order another one but it is now made in China. Feel like a cheaper product. Returned it promptly.
author: Ply
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 9 de marzo de 2016

title: Would be great except for the rust.
body:
The kettle works well, I've been using it on a gas stove, and the water comes out with an even temperature, no boiling on pour due to the spout being too hot.

That said, after only a month or so, the interior of the kettle is starting to rust. Nothing bad yet, but there are a few spots. I can only imagine they will get worse with time.

title: One good thing is it holds enough water for about 4 ...
body: This tea kettle feels very cheap. Made in China. One good thing is it holds enough water for about 4 cups of coffee (two large travel mugs). Now that I have it, I wish I'd gotten a model with a temperature reading on it for when I make tea.

title: Hario Versus Bonavita: Pour Over Coffee Kettle
body:
Purchased both Hario V60 and Bonavita BV3825ST non-electric gooseneck kettles from Amazon.

Country of Origin:
Hario: Made in Japan.
Bonavita: Made in China.

Capacity:
Hario: Practical capacity: .8 liter. Full capacity 1.2 liters.
Bonavita: Capacity: 1 liter.

Spout:
Hario: Gooseneck spout attached to body at lower point. Less water remains pooled at the bottom after complete pouring.
Bonavita: Gooseneck spout attached to body at higher point. More water remains pooled at the bottom after complete pouring.

Ergonomics:
Hario: Straight handle. Ergonomics not optimal.
Bonavita: Curved handle. Ergonomics better.

Product Material:
Hario: Stainless steel heavier and thicker. Seems higher quality steel. Handle good.
Bonavita: Stainless steel lighter and thinner. Handle good.

Quality of Construction:
Hario: Spout and handle attached with quality hardware. Seems more secure.
Bonavita: Spout and handle securely attached, but hardware appears to be less durable.

Design:
Hario: Lid does not fit tight. Will fall out when tipped at certain angle.
Bonavita: Lid fits tight. Will not fall out when tipped at certain angle. Handle has two screws located on underside at top, which impact finger comfort. Body has unfinished/uncurved inside top lip, which impacts hand comfort when cleaning inside body.

Appearance: Both look nice. Bonavita sits about an inch taller because of the design of the lid.

Pour Rate: Practically the same.

Recommendation: Both Hario and Bonavita will get the job done. I chose to keep Hario, because of the quality. But if money or style is a factor, Bonavita will work just fine. An alternative to these kettles, which I have not tried but appears to be of a very high quality, is the Kalita Wave Pot Kettle from Japan, priced at $107. Kalita 52073 Wave Pot Kettle
author: J. Dreesman
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 8 de mayo de 2012

title: it's all about the spout
body:
This product has one thing--and only one thing--going for it: its spout, which allows you to control the flow of water when brewing coffee using the pour-over method.

Otherwise, it has a few things going against it:

1. The price: it simply costs too much for what it offers.

2. The quality: it is very light-weight, flimsy stainless steel, and it rusts on the bottom (which is inexcusable for a tea kettle costing this much).

3. The design: It narrows toward the top, making it very inconvenient to wash and dry the inside (my had cannot fit through the top, and water gets trapped in the edges of the much wider base). If you fill the kettle and bring it to a rolling boil, water will actually boil out of the spout. Finally, it does not have any calibration lines on the inside indicating how many cups of water are in the kettle, which would have been handy.

Unless Hario happens to hold a patent on a kettle with a spout like this, there is room here for another company to design a much more solid, better designed product, in my opinion. Ideally, someone would make an electric kettle of this design (all stainless steel, no plastic of any kind anywhere, a narrow pour spout) that allowed you to set the temperature you want the water to reach and maintain. Hard to believe this is unavailable at any price, but I have yet to find it (please let me know in comments if you know of one!).

For now, we're stuck with the Hario, which does the job adequately, if a bit expensively.

UPDATE: Our wait is over, folks; the perfect kettle has arrived: Bonavita 1-Liter Variable Temperature Digital Electric Gooseneck Kettle

title: Nach drei Monaten Rost
body:
Mein Kaffeeequipement besteht aus ...

a.) Kalita Wave Pot Wasserkocher und Hario Buono Wasserkocher (1,2 l)
b.) Hario v60 Range Server Kaffeekanne (800 ml)
c.) Hario v60 Glass Dripper 02 und Kalita Wave Glas Dripper 185
d.) Solis Scala 166 KaffeemÃ¼hle

zu a.) Der Kalita Wave Pot hat inzwischen den Hario Buono bei mir abgelÃ¶st. Mit ihm kann ich endlich das heiÃŸe Wasser perfekt punktgenau dosieren, was nicht bedeutet, dass sich das Wasser mit dem Buono schlecht dossieren lÃ¤sst. Der Kalita ist zudem wertiger verarbeitet, und besteht aus - nicht spÃ¼lmaschinengeeigneten - rostfreiem Edelstahl. Und genau dies ist das eigentliche Manko des Hario, der bei mir nach 3 Monaten anfing leicht Rost anzusetzen. Ohne diese Eigenschaft, von der auch andere berichten, wÃ¼rde ich auch heute noch den Hario verwenden, der zudem durch seine pflegeleichte gebÃ¼rstete OberflÃ¤che 'glÃ¤nzt'.

zu b.) Die Hario v60 ist einfach nur perfekt. Meine uneingeschrÃ¤nkte Empfehlung.

zu c.) Die beiden Dripper passen beide auf die Hario v60. Seitdem ich anderenorts die nicht zusammengepresset verpackten Papierfilter von Hario entdeckt habe, ist der Hario insgesamt mein Favorit. Davor hatte der Kalita auch hier den Hario fast ganz verdrÃ¤ngt. Wenn ich mir aber einen groÃŸen Kaffee in meiner groÃŸen Bechertasse gÃ¶nne, verwende ich den Kalita, weil der auch dort noch einen festen Sitz hat. Vom Geschmack her kann ich keinen wirklichen Geschmacksunterschied feststellen. Die nicht gepressten Hario Filter haben aber einfach eine wunderschÃ¶ne Struktur, und das Auge trinkt ja bekanntlich auch mit ;-)

zu d.) Die Solis Scala hat alle meine Versuche, meinen selbst gebrannten Kaffee zu mahlen, beendet. Meinen Empfehlung fÃ¼r alle handgebrÃ¼hten Kaffeeliebhaber (inkl. French Press). Die MÃ¼hle scheint in kleinen Details verbessert worden zu sein. Bei meinem Exemplar sammelt sich jedenfalls praktisch kein Kaffeepulver mehr hinter dem AuffangbehÃ¤lter. Wenn ich alle paar Tage mit einem Pinsel nachfege, sind dies lediglich einige ganz wenige KrÃ¼mel, die sich dort angesammelt haben. Auch das Statikproblem kann ich so, wie vielfach geschildert, nicht nachvollziehen. Am inneren Rand des AuffangbehÃ¤lters bleibt etwas Kaffeemehl hÃ¤ngen, was fÃ¼r mich vÃ¶llig normal ist. FÃ¼r Espressoliebhaber kann ich diese MÃ¼hle aber nicht empfehlen. HierfÃ¼r mahlt sie nicht fein genug.

Wer sich Ã¼ber die vielen MÃ¶glichkeiten der Kaffeezubereitung informieren mÃ¶chte, dem empfehle ich die Seiten von Coffee Circle.

Und jetzt wÃ¼nsche ich allen viel SpaÃŸ und Freude beim GenuÃŸ ihrer nÃ¤chsten Tasse Kaffee.
author: Norbert
date: Revisado en Alemania el 12 de marzo de 2015

title: Didn't work for me on my induction burner.
body: I really wanted this kettle to work for me. I've always admired the design and simplicity. When my current kettle needed replacement, I ordered it immediately after checking to see if it was induction compatible. When it arrived, I put it on my burner but it was like it wasn't even there, no detection at all. It passes the classic test with a magnet but no joy. Very strange, since my existing kettle, which does not seem to be magnetic at all, boils better on the induction burner than any other heating appliance. They both have a similar diameter and base diameter so I am mystified. With regret I have had to return the kettle and order the same kettle I had before this to replace my current kettle.
author: Rodney Pike
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 8 de mayo de 2020

title: Rust
body:
As many other reviewers have stated, this product is not the same as the original Hario V60, which was manufactured in Japan, and is prone to rusting along the interior seam. This is a Chinese manufactured Hario V60 and is labeled as such on the bottom.

I followed all the manufacture guidelines, emptying and drying the kettle after boiling water in it (a fact I did not know when purchasing the kettle) and after a month of use began to see rust along the seam where the bottom of the kettle is attached to the walls. I continue to use the kettle with no noticeable effects to the water (color or taste). As far as fears about ingesting some of the rust, I have none. First, rust is simply iron oxide, which is non-toxic unless you consume a great deal of it, and second, rust is not soluble in water, so there is little fear of it tainting the water I boil in it.

Overall the kettle is great for what I purchased it for, making pour-over coffee with my Chemex coffee pot. Sadly, when it comes time to replace the Hario, I will be looking for a kettle that does not start to rust after a month of use following the manufacturer's care instructions. I had thought, after researching pour-over kettles, that I was buying an heirloom quality kettle in the V60 and that has not been the case.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 30 de enero de 2023

title: Tinny, the handle gets hot, doesn't whistle
body:
I guess I assumed all kettles whistled. I very often will put on water to boil in this thing, leave the kitchen, and totally forget that I left water boiling as it makes no noise. It's really easy to have happen, and I swear I'm not a forgetful person. It's only a matter of time until I leave the house with it on. I consider this a fire hazard! I would not buy a kettle that doesn't whistle.

Another thing is that this thing is made out of very thin metal, so it doesn't feel like it's worth almost $50, it feels more like $20.

Then the handle gets really hot unless you heat it at a pretty low temperature, which means you have to wait longer, which means you leave the kitchen and are likely to forget you put it on, since like I said this thing operates totally silently -- even when the water boils you can't hear anything, and my kitchen is right next to where I am. I still forget!

I would go down to your local grocery store (I don't know why I didn't do this) and buy one of theirs for $18, that's what the one's at my local Korean supermarket are selling for. They are made out of thin metal, about the same size, and they actually whistle!

This product is worth $25, not $50.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 20 de julio de 2022

title: 3.5 stars
body: This is the quintessential gooseneck kettle. It works well, but be warned it only does a liter of water--that's just enough for one standard french press, but not enough for one of the extra large french press carafes. I like the ergonomics of the handle, and I like that the lid goes in deep enough to stay secure. My major complaint is that there's no whistle and the holes on the lid are too small for a typical probe thermometer, so to figure out when it's done you can either leave the lid off and check it constantly or you can wait for it to boil over (which, incidentally, ejects the lid). My smaller complaint is that the knob on the lid is glued on, so it's not very secure. If you're just doing a standard french press or a chemex, this is good. If you need more water boiled, or if you don't like to watch your kettle like a hawk, you may want to look for another kettle--this one's handsome, but it has some flaws. 3.5 stars.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 31 de diciembre de 2016

title: Lightweight

author: Robert R. Buschbom
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 29 de diciembre de 2022

title: A love that might not last ?
body:
I loved my Hario drip kettle deeply, perhaps even inappropriately as it is an inanimate object. It does what it's designed to do better than anything else on the market--pour brewing-hot water over ground coffee beans in a controlled, precise fashion.
But my love affair ended yesterday after about 2 years of faithful and monogamous cohabitation. Up until yesterday I had never turned the heat on the electric stove to High, and thus the Hario looked basically new and worked perfectly. Then a babysitter made tea with it, turned the burner to High, and in only a few minutes time scarred my Hario for life. The metal's discolored yellowish over the entire surface, and the base inside, well, it looks like a rainbow. As it burned, it also stunk up half the house, again in under 5 minutes.
Reviews and the box say it's stovetop safe, but clearly this one wasn't. Looks like cheap metal and coatings are the culprit, leaving me to wonder about replacing this $50+ drip kettle. I still love Hario, but take my advice and don't let your love burn too hot.
author: Amazon Customer
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 13 de febrero de 2013

title: Great control over the pour, but watch for rust in a year. :-(
body:
UPDATE to my Original Post below: Its been a year and 3 months since I have purchased this kettle and used it almost every day since. The inside is starting to rust, which is inexcusable for something that cost's this much, and now, you guessed it, I cannot return it. BUY WITH CAUTION if you can live with the rust, its perfect for you. If you only want to use it for a year, then this is deal.

Original Post:
Great control over the pour and it made an excellent cup of coffee! However, I am a bit suppressed in the quality and build. It's very light and made from all stainless steel, no copper that I can find. I wish Hario would put a copper bottom on this unit to help distribute heat evenly. I did a test and my glass kettle heated 600 grams of water faster than the Hario. It seems to me that the Hario takes a lot longer to heat water than any other method I have used. Other than that, I like it.

body: I was really expecting a much better product considering this is a Hario. I have a Hario pour over filter and itâ€™s amazing, Iâ€™ve had it for 5 years now. I used a Bonavita kettle for my pour overs before and it was wonderful but since I needed to replace it I went with Hario this time. The top of the kettle doesnâ€™t actually snap on/in so once your water starts boiling the top almost flies off of the kettle. It also doesnâ€™t hold as much water as a Bonavita. author: Coffee lover
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 30 de abril de 2019

title: Not so great for a gas range, but it pours well
body:
This kettle is perfect for preparing pour-over coffee. I get a much better and more consistent bloom than I did using my regular tea kettle.

I have a gas range, and it's impossible to adjust the heat properly, regardless of burner size. If the heat is high enough to boil the water efficiently, the flames wrap around and put the plastic handle at risk. If it's low enough to protect the handle, it takes twice as long to heat the water as it does in my garden variety whistling tea kettle. We've reached a compromise. We heat the water in the regular kettle and then transfer it to this one. It works for us because we would keep the whistling kettle regardless. For those with limited space and a gas range, consider electric.
author: H. D
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 23 de julio de 2015

title: Form Over Function
body:
It is a nice looking kettle and I have had many compliments on it. It is made very well. As others have said, control of the water is perfect and does not drip. So now the negatives. If I fill it up more than half way the water starts spewing out of the spout causing a huge mess by the time it's ready to remove from the burner. So, to combat that, I only fill the kettle halfway. This said, it is not enough for two cups of tea or coffee.

Also, others have said the handle does not get hot. Mine does. It gets very hot and I have to use a oven mit to pour. Possibly this is because I have a gas stove?
author: Paul
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 5 de marzo de 2015

title: Good kettle for pour over coffee
body: As many of the other reviews state, this is a great kettle for making pour over coffee. I use it for my Chemex. I do agree that you must watch it, and take it off the heat as soon as the water boils or it will come out of the spout and get all over the place. It is also a little difficult to know when it is boiling since it doesn't whistle. Mine is stamped that it is made in Japan. It has started to discolor a little on the outside, but the inside is fine, and I never dry it out after use. For the price on Amazon I'm fine with the discoloring. If you buy this kettle at Williams and Sonoma it is twice the price.
author: Michelle Lieberson
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 5 de noviembre de 2015

title: Ordered direct from Amazon, got one labelled made in China. Buy the one from Japan.
body:
Called around and found one made in Japan (The box is labelled on bottom). There is a difference in the metal as well as the feel of the plastic used for the hand hold. Yes, it was ~$20 more local, but I'll happily buy something where I'm sure I;m not boiling liquid in a container that likely has heavy metals...

Manufacturer can say all they want that both China and Japan produce the same quality - they feel like two different products side-by-side.

Sellers take note, a LOT of customers do NOT want products from China as you can see from the review threads here.

body: Does the job, not sure what to make of this defect on the lid, which was present since day 1. Not sure if this is rust â€” no amount of scrubbing will get rid of it.

title: Eigentlich hÃ¼bscher Wasserkocher ...
body:
... der zwar nach nun ca. einem Jahr gebrauch keine Rostflecken bei uns hat wie bei anderen berichtet, aber gestern leider seinen Deckelgriff verloren hat.
Dieser hatte eine quasi homÃ¶opathische SchweiÃŸstelle, welche dann gestern keine Lust mehr hatte und sich einfach ablÃ¶ste. Wirklich schade, wird von mir aber vorerst mit Sekundenkleber behoben.

Denn an und fÃ¼r sich handelt es sich hier um eine hÃ¼bschen, schlicht gehaltenen Wasserkocher, der Tropffrei sehr gezieltes gieÃŸen ermÃ¶glicht und durch seine EntlÃ¼ftung im Deckel zwar nicht pfeift wenn das Wasser kocht, aber kurz bevor es kocht anfÃ¤ngt ein wenig zu rappeln und man so genau weiss, aha, jetzt ist der richtige Zeitpunkt und mein Wasser knapp Ã¼ber 90Â°C heiss.
Der angebrachte Haltegriff liegt gut in der Hand und ist auch gut isoliert, aufgrund des abgebrochenen Deckelgriffs mache ich mir nun allerdings ein wenig Sorgen um die Haltbarkeit.
Sollte sich da etwas ereignen, werde ich dies hier festhalten.

FÃ¼r die AtmosphÃ¤re eines gemÃ¼tlichen Kaffe Kochens ein schÃ¶nes Utensil, allerdings wohl mit kleinen MÃ¤ngeln und fÃ¼r den ausgeschriebenen Preis dann vielleicht eher mau.
author: maddaFreak
date: Revisado en Alemania el 19 de julio de 2017

title: Was able to make it look nearly good as new with some Barkeepers Friend
body:
I really wish this had a whistle or sound when it was boiling. Accidentally let it run dry once because I forgot about it. Was able to make it look nearly good as new with some Barkeepers Friend, but still a sad day.

Also the inside got a little rusty on day 1 of using it, not sure if that is common but not something I'm too worried about. The rust hasn't continued or made the water taste like iron, so I didn't try and return it.

A little low quality for the cost honestly, there must be higher quality goosenecks for the price.
author: Tim'sGradStudent
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 16 de febrero de 2016

title: Too small for standard 8-Cup French Presses
body: This product is excellent for the reason you're buying it. A nice even pour over your ground coffee and heats up quickly. The problem is, as others have stated, it's too small. You really can't even use this for a standard 8-cup French Press if you also use a little hot water to pre-heat your press bottom. Even being conservative, using enough water in this kettle will send it boiling over all over the place. It really needs to be much bigger, or at least offer a bigger size. Someone in a review said the usable volume is really .8 and I fully believe they're correct.
author: ThatMarriedGuy
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 5 de noviembre de 2015

title: Auf Indutkion ok, Wasserkocher war schneller
body:
Der gebogene, dÃ¼nne Ausguss ist perfekt fÃ¼r Kaffee und Tee. Leider dauert es auf unserem Induktionskochfeld (neu, Siemens) doch deutlich lÃ¤nger als ein herkÃ¶mmlicher Wasserkocher.

Auch wÃ¤re ein leichter Pfeifton (wie frÃ¼her) angenehm, da es so wie es ist eigentlich immer Ã¼berkocht, wenn man mehr als 50% fÃ¼llt.
author: AnKl
date: Revisado en Alemania el 25 de marzo de 2022

title: It is pretty cheaply made
body:
Using this correctly will bring your coffee preparation to the next level when using with a V60 pour over or a Chemex. Aeropress will not be affected, I really don't see how a Clever would be affected either.

It is pretty cheaply made. It looks nice and feels cheap. Mine hasn't rusted but I dry it out after every use. I fill this with a Zojirushi Water Boiler. I wouldn't feel right putting this guy on a stove burner. The loose fitting top lid drives me insane.

I would look for a different one, but this style of pouring kettle is what you need.
author: iBigChill
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de octubre de 2014

title: Excellent design, Metallic taste
body: I've been making coffee with the Hario v60 ceramic coffee filter with the help of my creuset teapot, which was much too heavy to pour comfortably/slowly. I purchased this coffee drip kettle to help and in many ways it is excellent- it is light, pours easily, contains the perfect amount of water. However, there is no protective coating inside, so causes a very strong metallic taste to the coffee now, which defeats the purpose. it's a shame- the kettle is so easy to handle, but what is the point of a bad cup of coffee?
author: Angela
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 19 de marzo de 2016

title: Solid Kettle, could be better
body:
This kettle is just alright. For what it costs they could add a digital thermometer to the lid but instead Hario has decided to sell a separate thermometer for $50. To me that's a complete rip off.

Pouring with this kettle is hassle free for the most part and the stainless steel finish stays nice with simple gentle cleaning periodically. Hario could easily make a better kettle, I guess they just don't feel the pressure or need to.
author: P. Brown
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 23 de febrero de 2017

title: Tener cuidado con envÃ­os desde JapÃ³n
body:
Retomo un comentario que otorga 5 estrellas y lo contrasto con mi opiniÃ³n:
1. "El diseÃ±o es hermoso": de acuerdo.
2. "la agarradera no se calienta", desacuerdo, se calienta y quema cerca de la base. Tuve que tomarla con mucha precauciÃ³n de la parte mÃ¡s alejada a la base.
3. "la tapa no se cae aÃºn cuando se sirvan las Ãºltimas gotas de lÃ­quido", Mhhh, no le veo relevancia al punto.
4. "y el control sobre el chorro de agua que sale de la cafetera es magnÃ­fico." De acuerdo y es relevante.
ConclusiÃ³n: Una tetera enviada desde JapÃ³n que multiplica el valor de origen por 3.5 con la mejor promociÃ³n de Amazon. Me sentÃ­ un tanto estafado, creo que debÃ­ comparar con otras marcas en tiendas fÃ­sicas. Lo harÃ© y si es justo modificarÃ© esta opiniÃ³n
author: CarlosNU
date: Revisado en MÃ©xico el 6 de mayo de 2019

title: Looks great, but feels cheap.
body: It feels kind of cheap, although it looks beautiful ... doesn't feel very solid or heavy-duty. And I wish it were larger, even though it's called the "large" size. It boils a very small amount of water. The pouring aspect, though, is super. It's the main reason I wanted it. The "care" instructions reaffirm its lack of sturdiness. I hope it lasts a long time, which would surprise me. Glad I got such a good price. 1.5 litres would be perfect.
author: Hazel Peartree
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de mayo de 2015

title: Made in China - Returned Right Away
body: Received a copy made in China, felt & looked OK but when you know it's supposed to made in China & Hario is known for their quality a product made in China is definitely a bummer. Packed this right back up & returned it as it's really a bit let down to see made in China for such a legendary kettle.
author: Jeremie Dupont
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 20 de diciembre de 2017

title: Rusted very quickly.
body:
Ok little teapot, but it spits water if you fill it even three quarters full, which is annoying at times but manageable.

My biggest complaint is that I don't always remember to empty the last little bit of water after use, and it rusted really quickly around the inside bottom edges. I would recommend storing upside down or completely dry after every use. (In all fairness the literature it comes with warns that it will rust if water is left inside).
author: Meg
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 28 de octubre de 2015

title: Good kettle but pretty pricey
body: Itâ€™s a pretty good kettle, easy to use. However, with the price I was expecting it to come with the thermometer built in, then it would be perfect.
author: Joey
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 29 de abril de 2020

title: I would not buy again
body: I have been eyeing one of these for a while, but I was surprised at just how small the kettle is. I would not recommend for those people who want to use a kettle for pour over coffee and other uses (hot water bottles for example).
author: Erica
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de enero de 2019

title: The steam holes, on one side of the the ...
body:
The steam holes, on one side of the the lid, are to be aware of. When reaching, to take off the stove, do not burn yourself.
We also noticed and do not understand why the lid sits in the pot so loose. This should be corrected.
On the up side this pour pot really makes a difference from a regular pot. The coffee tastes much smoother.
author: jessia
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 13 de junio de 2016

title: Looks good, performs well but rusts out.
body: From a functionality perspective, this works great. Very easy to control the spout, heats up well, handle feels good. Aesthetically it's very pleasing. However, it feels flimsy and after having it for just over 2 months it's rusting along the bottom seam on the outside and some spots on the inside. Disappointed in that, doesn't seem like this will be a long lasting kettle.
author: Francis
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de marzo de 2016

title: Handle gets hot with gas stove
body: Been using this for just over a year now. Although there's no whistle, you can easily lift the lid to see how things are going (the handle doesn't block the kid). Only complaint is that the handle gets hot with a gas stove - too hot to use with bare hands, in fact.
