title: Sputtering
body:
Like the pouring control and accuracy.
Dislike how air gets in the spout causing the water to sputter and splash. This occurs when about Â¼ of the water is remaining.
author: Bri in Mtl
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 4 de julio de 2018

title: Great, but rust is an issue
body: I've had this kettle for just over a month now, and it's been great, pour control is fantastic, however, rust has begun to form on the inside of the kettle which is rather disappointing. I do use the kettle frequently on an electric stove which I assume must has accelerated the issue, but, considering it is advertised as being able to do so, I am dissappointed.
author: James
date: Revisado en Reino Unido el 2 de junio de 2013

title: Made in Japan or China?
body:
Light, practical, fast-heating, but not convinced about where those are being made.
This is the second one we buy and the first one was clearly made in China.
Factories usually not moved from China to Japan, but rather the other way around.
author: Lilly
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 4 de enero de 2017

title: Way overpriced for the quality (or lack of) the design and workmanship
body: Disappointing quality of workmanship given the price. The seams are very obvious, almost looks like it was glued together. Not impressed with the value for the money. It should be a $5-$10 item.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 12 de julio de 2017

title: Spill water
body: I like the design. Itâ€™s nice and sleek. But everytime when the water is boiling, it always spills out from the spout. Even when I put very little water in there.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 1 de agosto de 2018

title: Loser Griff
body: Eigentlich war ich mit der Kanne sehr zufrieden. Der Griff wackelte am Anfang leicht, jedoch nicht wirklich auffÃ¤llig. Leider fiel mir heute beim anheben des gefÃ¼llten, heiÃŸen Kessels eben jener Griff ab. Mir ist zum GlÃ¼ck nichts passiert, nur um die Kanne ist es schade.

title: already rusting after 2 months
body: I got this as a gift for my brother for christmas and by february he told me it was already rusting. I would go with another that is similar to this one but less expensive because of the name. looks cool but disappointed.
author: Steve
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 18 de abril de 2016

title: Looked great but there was a hairline crack in the base ...
body: Looked great but there was a hairline crack in the base causing the product to leak. I ultimately returned it but I am giving 3 stars because although product was defective they processed my return quickly with no hassles. Also, it was a good looking kettle albeit very tiny.
author: Pink_elephant_liz
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 20 de febrero de 2015

title: Should be labeled as 'Made in China'.
body: This kettle is made in China. Quality is not up to the same standards as the Japanese made kettle. But it works - so far.

title: I was really disappointed in the quality of the drip kettle
body:
I was really excited when I ordered my items for V60 coffee brewing. I gotta be honest, I was really disappointed in the quality of the drip kettle.
It serves it's purpose like it's suppose to but for $40 I expected better quality. It's just cheap.

date: Revisado en MÃ©xico el 18 de julio de 2017

title: Things you need to know about this product before buying
body:
Things you need to know before buying:

I used a regular pot with a pour spout 3 months before I purchased this kettle. The following points are based primarily on the differences I noticed between the regular pot and the kettle.

1. The pour control with the kettle is VASTLY superior to the control you get with a product with a normal "spout" area. The kettle's thin spout and long distance the water has to travel gives you a small, smooth stream in which to pour on your coffee grounds.

2. Because of the points in #1, the kettle allows you to pour water over the coffee smoothly and at a consistent pace, therefore giving you an EVEN extraction of your coffee, which translates to a nice, consistent taste in your cup. This is what you're going for.

3. The kettle holds enough water for about 5 regular cups of coffee (i.e. it holds ~40 ounces of water). I own the 40oz Chemex coffee maker, so for me, a full kettle = a full pot of coffee.

4. The kettle is SAFE to boil your water with. However, the conductivity of the kettle's metal is not as good as a standard pot, so it will take you roughly twice as long to boil water in the kettle versus boiling it in a pot. (I bought a separate water kettle for this reason.)

5. As mentioned in other reviews, this kettle is hard to clean. The opening is hard to get your hand into, and the small spout makes everything but a pipe cleaner impossible to clean the inside. If you live in an area with hard water (like I do), then you'll want to filter your water before using this kettle to cut down on the deposit build up.

Hands-down, this kettle gives you the control you need to make an excellent cup of coffee. If you brew your coffee through a pour over method (such as the Chemex), then this is the kettle for you. Other than the cleaning difficulty and long(ish) time it takes for this kettle to boil water, I highly recommend this product.

'Hope you found this helpful!
author: CapriS.
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 27 de julio de 2010

title: Almost great
body:
Was skeptical at first--what difference could a long spout make in pour-over brewing? Plenty--it allows for the precise placement necessary to extract the best from your fresh grounds and produce the perfect cup. Heats much faster than one would expect. Stay-cool handle (knob too) is ergonomic, and the entire kettle is nicely balanced, lightweight but not flimsy. Lid stays put, so no need to hold it in place while pouring (which you can do one-handed).

Four drawbacks: no audible signal as to when the waterâ€™s boiling--you need to see steam coming from the vents & spout. Before you set the kettle to boil, make sure the vents are on the opposite side from the handle to avoid scalding yourself. The spout bottom is set so low that it will splatter all over the stove if you fill it with more than an inch above the inside "hole.: But the biggest flaw, IMHO, is that the angle of the spout is too gentle (not tall or acute enough) and if the water is hot enough, it'll splash out the spout-- making a precise spiral pour difficult-to-impossible.

(I've since tried the tall Jirushi pot, but its handle got screaming hot and its loop-shape makes it a challenge to use with most potholders or mitts-- it's also too heavy & unwieldy to use with an OveGlove (the only mitt that comfortably fits) and its lid falls off unless held in place with a potholder or towel in the other hand, which poses a fire hazard with a gas range). The Jirushi's spout opening is too large for a precise drip. Just ordered a Stagg in stainless--will report back on that. But meanwhile, I will keep using this Hario and wait till it cools for a few seconds before pouring.
author: Sandra L. Andina
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 21 de marzo de 2015

title: Very nice Kettle, appears to be well-made
body:
Very nice Kettle, appears to be well-made, and the pouring control is the star of the show here. The pour-over coffee lovers will be hard-pressed to find a better spout, and I would have never believed there would be a difference in the taste between pouring water over the top of the grounds in the Chemex versus a slow, sustained and gentle pour-over, but there is. My Canal Town Coffee Roasters Ugandan Whole Bean really was able to shine, and the cherry and citrus notes that I had not gotten with a quick dump over, were quite evident. Excellent pouring control and spout.

Okay, here's the other side of the coin. It took more than eleven minutes to boil 32 ounces of water in this kettle. I have a new, glass-top range, and this seemed like a very long time to boil water. Granted, the water was cold, from the filtered refrigerator water dispenser, so perhaps I did not give ample time to boil cold water, but I can microwave that same temperature water in a Pyrex container, and it takes me six minutes to boil that amount, so the reviewer who stated it took double the time to boil water in this kettle, was not far off.

My feeling is that I will boil the water, and transfer the boiling water to this kettle, thereby creating just enough cool down to commence the pour, and I can get the best of both worlds.

Four star rating with a star demerit for boiling time being longer than expected, but the construction, quality, look, and the amazing pouring aspect of the spout, makes this a highly-recommended purchase for the pour-over coffee connoisseur.

Enjoy!
~syf
author: Stealyerface
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 14 de agosto de 2014

title: Solid, quality build, only let down by a very loose fitting lid
body:
Despite a few people saying the build quality of their made in China kettle is poor, the one I've received is definitely made in Japan (stamped on the box and also engraved in the sole plate) and is built very well given how light it is. It offers incredible control over pouring water and is easy to use.

My only minus point (and it's very much personal opinion) goes to the lid. It's well made, but it's very loose - if you turn the kettle upside down it falls out. Now, I never intend on doing that when it's full of boiling water, but I'd just prefer one that offered some resistance to coming out. On a positive note, whilst this kettle doesn't whistle, the loose lid does rattle when the water's boiling giving you some audible indication to come and take it off the heat.
author: BenP
date: Revisado en Reino Unido el 26 de junio de 2022

title: Not meant to boil 1.2L
body: Smaller than expected. I was given the impression this would be capable of boiling 1.2L, but the box says it's designed to hold 0.8. 1.2 L fills it to just below the brim. Aside from that, it's a beautiful kettle, and mine was made in Japan
author: Andrew H.
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 12 de junio de 2023

title: Love this pot but pay attention
body:
I love the look and ease of pouring from this pot. It makes pouring for a pour over coffee much easier!
The only thing is you canâ€™t turn your back on it. When it boils (quickly on my induction) it will erupt if itâ€™s not taken off t the heat immediately. I donâ€™t actually mind it-it is just part of my coffee making ritual, which I enjoyâ˜•ï¸
author: Cindy NS
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 9 de abril de 2023

title: Good but some issues you might want to know about
body:
So I finally got into the pour over method for making coffee on the weekends. I still rely on the drip machine for weekday mornings. I have a french press as well.

I used to use a regular kettle without the gooseneck and it was horrible at control. I finally burned that kettle so on buying a new one I found this to be the best choice without breaking the bank.

Pros:
- Sturdy compared to the other brand (saw it in person at a coffee shop)
- great control over pouring

Cons:
- like others have said, takes awhile to heat up. I am using it on a gas viking grill so it's not like it's underpowered
- handle gets hot (but like all pots/pans on a gas grill, this happens)
- lid doesn't stay on for a full tilt, it will slide off so you better catch it
- *most annoying thing that isn't a dealbreaker* if you choose to heat it up with water inside, water will start to pour out on full boil from the gooseneck. Obviously you buy a kettle to boil water but I have read reviews it's easier to bring water to a boil in another vessel and then transfer over. That is just ridiculous as what's the point of buying this thing?

Overall a good kettle with a very specific purpose. Obviously you're already a big enough coffee person to get into this so you will obviously take the negatives for those couple of positives.
author: P N
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 9 de octubre de 2013

title: Great for coffee lovers!
body:
This kettle is perfect if you want the full experience of making a single superb cup of coffee at home. Because the thin spout comes from the bottom of the kettle, it provides a much more easily controlled stream of hot water to pour over your grounds and watch them swell to form that lovely coffee dome. If you just want a cup of coffee right now and don't care about the process of brewing one excellent cup of coffee at a time, then get a drip coffee maker. But know this: this kettle and a good burr grinder will allow you to take even ordinary coffee beans like those from 8 O'clock Coffee and produce an eminently delicious cup of coffee equally anything you will get from a gourmet coffee shop, save those that use the most expensive beans, like Kona or Blue Mountain.
The only concern I have about this kettle is the fact that when the water is boiling and even though there are three little holes that indicate there is steam coming through them, that steam is invisible until you turn off the heat source. Then you see the steam streaming through the holes. So be careful when you are removing the kettle from the stove. Use a pot holder and don't put your fingers over those holes unless you enjoy the smell of singed fingers along with the coffee aroma.
author: P. Matychuk
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 11 de enero de 2014

title: Nice kettle for cheap!!!
body: So far it's been a good addition to our tea supplies. Used it for about 3 months and no signs of rust. The first 2 months we used reverse osmosis filtered water only and the kettle stayed looking brand new. Then we got lazy and used sink water. Shortly afterwards white spots started appearing on the inside of the kettle. The manufacturer actually warns you of this on the box. It's due to minerals in the water or something and isn't harmful. I guess we should have listened. Either way it's still a good kettle and keeps water warm for a decent amount of time given how thin the material is. The best thing about it is that it pours boiling water safely and doesn't spill. The handle is also nice but don't leave it directly over the stove's heat or it would probably melt. We have an electric stove so no flame to worry about. I'd be extra cautious if using a gas stove. I give it a 4 out of 5 for now. The material could be thicker and keep the water hot longer but then again for the price what do you expect? It also doesn't whistle but you can tell when it's ready. The top lid will start making a chattering noise and you'll see hot steam shooting out of the little holes on the lid.
author: Swerve240
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 16 de febrero de 2015

title: Great control for a pour over
body: This kettle works excellent for controlled pour over. I knocked one star off for two reasons. One being that it really isn't big enough for my 1 litre coffee pot- I end up being short by 1/2 to 2/3 of a cup due to the absorbption by the coffee grounds. I thought this being 1.2 litre size it would compensate but it doesn't and I have to manually top up the water to get the last full cup. It's not the end of the world, but my husband wouldn't want the extra fussing if he decided to make the coffee, so no sleeping in for me! The second is more safety related. I don't see a mention of this through any of the other reviews and perhaps it is because I fill mine right up, but when the kettle gets to a full boil it starts shooting spurts of boiling hot water out of the spout! I have to be extra vigilant to not leave the room until the kettle has reached its boiling point for fear of some disaster taking place. I have found if I am willing to wait a little longer for my water to boil that I can use a lower heat setting (this is a propane gas stove we are using btw- electric may not be the same) and it is easier to catch before it starts spouting off.
author: Robinf
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 23 de noviembre de 2015

title: Hario V60 Buono Coffee Drip Kettle, 1200ml
body:
We were looking for a small tea pot to set on a warmer for small gatherings. We wanted something stable, would look good on a warmer, and had good pouring control. We tested this with the GROSCHE ALEXANDRIA Stainless Steel Teapot Warmer and the Richland Tealight Candles White Unscented Set of 125. The Hario fits nicely. Note it is the 1200 mL size. We put in 1L of 80Â°C water, and the warmer kept it at 74Â°C for hours. We then removed half the water and added more at room temperature, and the warmer heated it to over 68Â°C.

We live in an area with hard water, and filter our water for drinking and cooking. Teas and coffee are much better for it. We don't see ourselves putting tea or coffee in this pot.

It lost a star because:
It does not have any calibration lines on the inside indicating the recommended fill level, AND it is deceptive to look into it when filling, because of reflections.
It has a pushed-on plastic handle; we'd have preferred SS.
Does not dry out easily...now this is strictly a design comment...we like the design, but it simply didn't dry out sitting on the counter. I placed it on the wood stove for a bit, and it dried quickly.
author: Weathered Soul
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 22 de enero de 2014

title: very good range top kettle for pour over coffee.
body: You have to be careful when gripping handle as it is close to hot kettle. Would like a whistle or indicator when it's boiling. I set a timer and lift cap to see if boiling. I wanted an electric pot but all made in China. This is made in Japan, a plus.
author: HP38
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 5 de septiembre de 2022

title: Shamefully the best
body:
My wife bought me one of these a couple of years ago when I was getting serious about single cup pour-over coffee. I liked it a lot for the design and the easy control over the pour. It feels a bit thin, enough so that I was convinced it was aluminum (it claims to be stainless steel), and it seems really expensive for what it is. So, after the original was left behind during a cross-country move, I decided to look into all the kettle options.

...they all suck. While I still feel this kettle is grossly overpriced, it's a very reasonable value compared to other kettles. Basically, you need to have a kettle with a long, narrow spout if you're going to do pour over. And stainless is highly preferable to aluminum. That narrows down the field to about 3 or maybe 4 kettles. This is the best, and best value, unfortunately. These ought to be able to be mass produced for $3-5. How can Hario charge in the range of $50? Because no one else is offering a better (or even comparable) kettle for less.
author: Flankencharp
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de septiembre de 2013

title: This is a tea kettle as well as a coffee drip kettle.
body: I ordered this after I saw a picture of it on Amazon. I thought it was beautiful, but because it is called a "Coffee Drip Kettle" I was afraid I might not be able to use it as a tea kettle for just boiling water. Not to worry. It is a tea kettle, period. Don't know why they call it a coffee kettle. That just seems confusing. Anyway, it looks as great in real life than it does in the ad. The only reason I gave it four stars instead of five is that the kettle bottom is small in diameter, compared with a regular kettle. So, if you put it on a large burner to boil the water, you will risk burning or even melting the handle. You either need to remember to place it carefully so the handle isn't exposed to the heat, or use a smaller burner which will take longer to boil. I don't know if it is clear from the illustration, but it extends high so it holds at least a quart of water.
author: Tony L
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 10 de marzo de 2015

title: Einfach ein schÃ¶nes StÃ¼ck !
body: Da ich meinen Kaffee per Hand filtere , habe ich in einschlÃ¤giger Literatur nach Tipps gesucht und bin dem Vorschlag eine Schwanenhalskanne zu benutzen , gefolgt . In dieser speziellen Kanne von Hario hat das Kaffeewasser die ideale Temperatur , nachdem man es aus dem Wasserkocher in die Hario gegossen hat .Also kann ich bloss in diesem Bereich einen praktischen Nutzen feststellen. Was mir an dieser Kanne aber besonders gut gefÃ¤llt ist, ist das Design , sie steht bei Nichtbenutzung immer auf dem Herd und ist schon beim Betreten der KÃ¼che der Hingucker ! Von daher finde ich auch den Preis vÃ¶llig in Ordnung . .
author: ellibys
date: Revisado en Alemania el 14 de abril de 2021

title: Don't try tightening the knob on the lid!!!
body: A quality product. Same kettle used at many specialty coffee shops I go to across the U.S. However, this particular kettle gets one star knocked off my review because the knob on the kettle lid seemed loose when I unpacked it. I thought I could simply hand tighten the knob only to have the tack weld holding the threaded stem for the knob snap off in my hand using minimal twisting pressure. No worries, I was able to fix it quickly for less than $1.00 by buying a stainless steel machine screw, a stainless lock washer and drilling a hole in the lid where the stem was tacked on. Other than that minor inconvenience it is a great product. I have already bought it a second time so my kid can do pour over coffees at his house. The second kettle didn't have a loose knob on the lid.
author: Amazon Customer
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 3 de febrero de 2017

title: Great kettle, make sure to check the seller
body: This is a great kettle, but make sure you check the seller. I've gotten more into pour over coffee and was looking for the perfect kettle. I was torn between the Hario and Kalita, but went with Hario after reading reviews. The kettle heats up fast and the spout gives great control. I was hesitant after reading reviews that it was made in China, but ordered anyway. The first one came directly from Amazon and was the counterfeit Chinese version - the packaging was bumped out like the kettle had been jammed in a too-small box, and while the writing on the box was Japanese it had "Made in China" stamped on it. I sent it back and ordered again from UJC Mart Japan; this seller had the Japanese version and the quality is like night and day. Definitely recommend for the function of the kettle, but make sure you get a good seller.

title: Nice, but if you want the Thermometer, think twice.
body:
It's nice and durable, but is it worth that much money? I had it for a few months, so i can't tell long term.
the optional Thermometer was the reason why i bought the Hario one, but WHAT A MISTAKE. their thermometer is poorly made, the battery compartment lid BREAKS easily, and you have to order EITHER C or F. it doesn't seem to withstand the heat either (WTF eh)...
Back to the pot, so, if you want to get this because of the thermometer, don't bother.
author: Have a nice day :)
date: Revisado en CanadÃ¡ el 10 de mayo de 2020

title: Loose lid, but otherwise functions well.
body:
I have used this only a few times, having just received it a few days ago. I had read in my research on various gooseneck kettles that this one had a lid that was prone to fall off as you poured. This has been my experience. Unless you are not wanting to use most all of the water in the kettle, then there will need to be some attention given to the lid because it does not sit firmly on the kettle.

Also, I have a flat-top electric stove top. I put this on a burner that is nearly the same size as the base of the kettle, yet the handle does get hot. It is not so hot that handling becomes challenging or dangerous, but it is something that I noticed anyway.

But for the price, overall I would say I am pleased.
author: mzimm
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 22 de mayo de 2016

title: I wish they had stopper and whistle
body: Great product. I think it takes me over secen minutes to boil full 1 litre. The only downside or more of an annoyance is that gooseneck starts spitting boil water out first bsfore any sort of indication. They should add some sort of removable whistle to stop boiling water out.
author: Nischal
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 26 de enero de 2022

title: Good product. Would prefer MIJ or clarity in origin.
body:
Good product. Have other Hario stuff that is manufactured in Japan. This, however is manufactured in China.

Build and material quality is good. No rough edges or poor cuts or bad welds. Purchased a different brand/model prior and it was a train wreck. The spout was cut poorly and was left so sharp that it could have cut rope. The metal body had odd machine grease or cleaner on it and the metal was finished poorly overall. This Hario however is built well and functions great for our uses: pour over coffee and general kettle use for tea and oatmeal, etc.

Knocked off one star for the confusion/obfuscation on the products manufacturing origin. Nothing Xenophibic - just expected that Hario stuff was made in Japan and did not find anything contrary in the description.
author: Sette/Otto
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 11 de noviembre de 2016

title: Great Kettle, but the handle gets hot
body: I like the product. My only complaint is the handle gets too hot to hold. Nothing a towel can't fix, but it's a flaw, so 4 stars.

date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 22 de marzo de 2022

body: Did a lot of research on kettles and this was constantly reviewed as the best. Perfect and from Japan as advertised.

title: The lid is too loose
body: I put it on an induction stove and the lid of the kettle popped up when the water was boiled. Personally, I think the lid is just too loose. It falls out easily if you pour water at a steep angle. I suggest they refine the design put a bit of friction between the lid and the body.

title: Made in China
body: I did not use product. I purchased and when I received the kettle I opened it to inspect and I love the look of the kettle, and thatâ€™s the main reason I purchased. I was hoping to get lucky as some of the reviewers had received an authentic version made in Japan but unfortunately the one I received was an imitation version from China with an imitation box that looked to be to small for kettle. Was made cheap and was same price as what you can get an authentic version for. I just didnâ€™t like the false description and returned it same day as it was received.
author: _N_R_P_
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 15 de marzo de 2019

title: Perfect Pour-Over Tool
body:
After receiving a Beehouse drip cone for as a gift, I started brewing my own coffee instead of going to Starbucks every morning. However, my set-up was primitive, bordering on barbaric. Without a scale or a kettle, I was estimating the amount of beans and water that I needed. After brewing some subpar and inconsistent coffee, I invested in a scale and this Hario kettle.

Pros:
- Easy to control the amount and speed of water flow (I was previously using a wide-mouthed measuring cup)
- Does anything you'd expect a kettle to do

Cons:
- Seemingly more expensive than a device of this sort should cost
- Hard to fully dry the inside (to avoid rust)

All in all, this is a great kettle that costs $20 more than I would usually hope to spend (not that I'll be returning it any time soon)

title: Nice coffee drip kettle
body: This review is for the Hario V60 Buono Coffee Drip Kettle 1.2L. My version was ordered directly from Amazon. From the earlier reviews I have read, it seems that earlier orders of this 1.2L kettle sold by Amazon were manufactured in Japan. But the one I received in December 2015 was made in China. I consider this kettle quite an expensive purchase, and for the price paid, I had expected it to be made in Japan, but it is not... Although it is rated at 1.2L, the recommended maximum water fill should not exceed 800ml for safety reasons (as it might overflow due to the water boiling over the lid). Overall it's quite a well made kettle & pours well, and served its intended purpose, but a little too pricey...
author: ML
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 20 de diciembre de 2015

title: Just right size
body: This is perfect for quickly heating water for a small pot of tea or French press coffee.
author: Deborah Edwards
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 9 de octubre de 2022

title: Gold standard for brewing coffee. Not ideal for boiling.
body:
If you're looking at this you've probably seen it at coffee shops and read about why you should use one. As far pouring a consistent stream of water for brewing your coffee this is a great kettle.

Where it falls flat is in the material it's constructed out of. If you're going to use this in conjunction with another heating device, such as an electric kettle or a water boiler this is a 5 star product. If you're using this on your stove top, the water will take a little longer to boil than you'd like. Stainless is unfortunately a poor thermal conductor.

The design is gorgeous, and it's perfect for brewing coffee. Stove top boiling is definitely for the patient or those who don't mind.
author: ThisGuyReads
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 2 de septiembre de 2015

title: cute little kettle
body: Works as described; like it much better for pour over coffee than the more expensive brand. For those of you who care, the bottom of kettle is magnetic but the rest is not. --I buy really good Stumptown coffee and grind the beans myself. I really do not see much of a difference in coffee however, whether I pour the just off boil water all at once or let it bloom and brew, it tastes the same to me. Bought it more for the ritual and the show I think. Cannot make but two cups of coffee at a time--so not for guests. The fact that it has come down in price is a plus.
author: Grandma Vic
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 14 de agosto de 2015

title: Great for AeroPress coffee making
body:
Arrived somewhat quickly, read instructions and says to wash 2-3 times before using... then boil water in it 2-3 times before using. Not too sure about all that, but I did it. Seems to heat up relatively quickly. There are three steam holes in the lid, but in the times I boiled water, only 1 time when it boiled did steam come out. Make sure to dry out after use so as not to develop rust on the product.

I will have to see how long it lasts.

Pouring is very nice, but handle heats up quickly when boiling over gas flame stovetop... so wear a glove.

title: SchÃ¶ner Kessel ... aber der Ausguss...
body: Der Kessel (made in Japan) ist in Ordnung und sieht gut aus. LÃ¤rmt beim Kochen, das macht aber nichts, ist sogar hilfreich, weil er ja keine Pfeife hat. Das Problem liegt im AusgieÃŸer Das geschwungene RÃ¶hrchen zwingt zur Geduld und zum langsamen GieÃŸen, das ist gut. Aber es verkalkt schnell und dann bleibt von dem schÃ¶nen geschwungenen Wasserstrahl nach und nach nur ein Rinnsal. Man mÃ¼sste das RÃ¶hrchen nach jedem Gebrauch reinigen. Pfeifenreiniger sind zu kurz und nicht dick genug, FlaschenbÃ¼rsten zu dick. Wenn jemand eine LÃ¶sung fÃ¼r dieses Problem hat â€“ bitte unbedingt verÃ¶ffentlichen!
author: Sonja Sommer
date: Revisado en Alemania el 7 de agosto de 2018

title: Outstanding Kettle
body:
Pros:
Heats fast
Solid construction
Great ergonomics
Ideal for pour over coffee as well as teas

Cons:
Boiling signal

The only thing I'd change on this kettle would be something to make it whistle or let you know it's boiling. I'm not sure how hard it is to implement some sort of steam-induced whistling action, but surely it couldn't be detrimental to the overall design. Can it? It's got steam holes in the lid so you can see when it's ready. But if you're like me and step away for a bit, you better remember that you put the kettle on and check on it. Perhaps I just need to be less absent-minded.
author: JPB
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 16 de septiembre de 2013

title: Good Kettle
body: I got this for xmas and have been using it daily for three months now. Water boils in about ten minutes on a gas stove, which is enough time for me grind my beans and prep everything else. I haven't had any rust issues and I leave water in almost every day. I only clean it when it gets grease splashes from cooking and only then do I dry it. Pour control is good and it works great for my pour-overs. Would definitely recommend.
author: Onoku
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 24 de marzo de 2017

title: Precise Pouring
body: This kettle has held up pretty well so far. It's not a super sturdy kettle and you have to remember to not fill it up to the top otherwise water will spray out from the nozzle when it starts to boil. It's pretty small and will serve no more than three people. At the same time with this size kettle you won't waste coffee or water because you never make more than you need. It's a cute and slightly quirky looking kettle that will grow on you the longer you use it. The spout is the most unique feature both visually and functionally and it offers a very precise pour.
author: Sybil Carpenter
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 3 de julio de 2014

title: SchÃ¶nes Design mit gut dosierbarem Ausguss.
body:
SchÃ¶ner Wasserkessel. Ich nutze ihn fÃ¼r das AufgieÃŸen von BrÃ¼hkaffee und Tee. Der Durchmesser und die Dosierbarkeit des Wasserstrahls ist fÃ¼r dir Zwecke gut geeignet.
Der Kessel sieht gut aus und macht einen haltbaren Eindruck. Auf unserem Ceranfeld kocht das Wasser im Topf allerdings schneller als in diesem Kessel, was ein kleiner Nachteil ist. Preislich noch im Rahmen, wobei man das Design und die Marke mit zahlt.
author: PG
date: Revisado en Alemania el 22 de diciembre de 2019

title: Looks nice
body: A little pricey for what it is. Just got mine last week and thankfully I received one that was made in Japan. Looks good but only time will tell it's durability.

title: Great product, wish it had more bang for the buck
body: Control, control, control. This is why you get a Buono. Control is essential for good pour overs, and this fits the bill. Although it says that you can boil water in it, since the product is lighter aluminum, I haven't thought about putting it on top of my gas stove. Since it is lighter aluminum material, it has the tendency to lose heat rather quickly. Nevertheless, I understand why people get these now. It's light, accurate, aesthetically pleasing, and well made. I rated it four stars because it seems needlessly overpriced and the heat retention isn't the best.

title: Good with an important caveat
body: I use this daily and it does pretty much what it is supposed to do. My one gripe would be that if the kettle is filled more than 60 or so percent once it starts boiling water has a tendency to come out of the spout while it is on the stove. I have never had an issue but this could be problematic for some especially if there are children or pets around. I have taken to 'aiming' the spout to where it will not over shoot the stovetop.
author: Local Man
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 5 de febrero de 2016

title: Empfehlung!
body:
Nach Ã¼ber sieben Monaten in Gebrauch macht dieser Kessel einen guten Gesamteindruck.
Ich benutze ihn auf einem Induktionskochfeld. Wenn das Wasser richtig sprudelt es sein, dass der Deckel schonmal vom Kessel hÃ¼pft. DafÃ¼r ein Stern Abzug.

Ansonsten lÃ¤sst sich das Wasser beim AusgieÃŸen super dosieren und er ist gut zu reinigen.

Rost kann ich bisher nicht feststellen. Ich wische aber nach jedem Kochen mit einem trockenen Tuch durch.

Ich wÃ¼rde ihn wieder kaufen. Am liebsten in der KupferausfÃ¼hrung, aber dann funktioniert das Induktionsprinzip leider nicht mehr ;)
author: Siddy P.
date: Revisado en Alemania el 7 de septiembre de 2017

title: No worries
body:
I have been using the "stove top" and electric models for 3 months. (Electric at work, stove at home.)

So far no issues with either.

I don't let water sit in the kettles, and I use the stove top model for pouring only. I heat my water in a more robust enameled steel kettle. The traditional kettle has a much wider base and is better for heating and the Hario is far better for pouring. It only takes a few seconds to pour one kettle into the other.

It should be made of heavier steel for this price and this is why only 4 stars.

title: Pretty Good Product
body: This product is great for pour over coffee. The design is great and looks good in any kitchen. The are two things that are less desirable: The handle gets hot, but is easily resolved by using a hot pad to remove off the burner The second issue is that the kettle does not whistle when boiling and if the kettle is full of water, the water will get pushed out of the spout at time of boil. Both issues are not major issues and overall it is a good product.

title: Almost perfect
body:
Make no mistake, if you're a tea or coffee fanatic this bottom fed pot is the tool for you...as long as you want one mug at a time.

The pot it replaced had no indication of its capacity and we didn't think to try measuring it before placing our order. The picture and description didn't really give adequate clue of its size either. So just be warned, if you're a double Starbucks mug household you'll be filling this kettle twice.

If this were a 2+ liter pot I'd give it five stars in a heartbeat.

title: This kettle is great. I bought this about six months ago and ...
body: This kettle is great. I bought this about six months ago and has had water in it since then. I use it at least once a day for coffee or tea and it does what it's made to do. The thin spout makes for a very controlled pour if your using it for brewing coffee in the pour over method. It has yet to show any signs of corrosion despite being used so often and I expect it will last a very long time. Quality product.

title: Beautiful product. Only giving 4 stars due to size ...
body:
Beautiful product. Only giving 4 stars due to size of item. It says 1.2l, but according to the optimal capacity line, that's definitely not the amount of water you can boil in it.
So if I'm using it for the Chemex caraffe, I fill it to capacity to pour over from another larger kettle.
It is just as the image, very pretty.

title: First rusted, second works like a charm.
body:
I love this kettle, it is perfect for pour over coffee and it feels wonderful in the hand. There is one HUGE problem and that is RUST!!! On the inside of the kettle, around the seams at the base, rust has developed. Not a lot of rust, but after two weeks this should not have occured. Mind you, when I am finished using my kettle in the morning, I always wipe it down inside and out. I think Japanese made and that usually means impeccable quality, but somehow this kettle fails to perform. I love the design and feel of this kettle, but where is the quality control???
UPDATE 2-17-2012: I checked at my local coffee shop, Catalina Coffee, and their Hario kettles are perfect with no rust. Maybe in their rush to make new kettles due to the popularity of the pourover, Hario's quality control slipped a bit.
UPDATE 2-23-2012: I tried to return this with the company I purchased with on Amazon called M Deals, here is a segment of their response to me about my return request: "Unfortunately, we cannot accept return at this moment. You have been using this kettle for 3 weeks. The item you carry is exactly same item with the one from your local coffee shop. Hario kettle we are selling is the original made in Japan product. You need to use drinking water and clean it after each use. Please let us know if you have any other questions. Thank you for contacting M Deals." WHAT?????!!!!!! I have used it for 3 weeks and it developed rust, and that's acceptable to them? I need to use drinking water????!!!!! What do they think that I have been putting in there to make my coffee?? Unfortunately you run into a bad vendor on Amazon, and M DEALS DOES NOT STAND BEHIND WHAT THEY SELL and they do a horrible job of taking care of their customers. Buy the Hario kettle from anybody but M Deals!!!
UPDATE 5-20-2012: In March, I purchased a new non rusting Hario kettle from the nice folks at Seattle Coffee Gear. I love it!! My other rusting Hario kettle has been reassigned to watering herbs in my garden and for watering my Bonsai trees. It performs like a champ in its new job!!
author: William Cramer
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 29 de enero de 2012

title: Essential for making a good cup of drip/pour-over coffee
body:
To be honest, I was hesitant to pay so much for a kettle. I'd already bought the ceramic Hario coffee dripper and wasn't sure it made sense to shell out more than the double for the kettle.

If you're reading through these reviews, you've already gotten it into your head that this kettle might make a difference when you are making a cup of coffee at home. To us, it makes a huge difference.

The diameter and curve of the spout gives you so much more control over the rate of flow and volume of water you are pouring over your grounds versus a standard kettle. Controlling the level of water and where you pour that water is key to getting good flavor out of your coffee. If you're buying good beans, have a good grinder, and have a coffee dripper, but are not controlling the flow of water, you might as well just use a standard coffee maker and not bother.

So do yourself a favor and get the Drip Kettle. Then read up on the technique and practice until you're happy with it: [...]

Finally, think of every cup of coffee you pour yourself at home as another $3 you won't be paying at a great coffee place. Do this 17 times and you can afford this kettle.

Some additional notes:

I have a Zojirushi water boiler at home so I've never used this kettle to boil water. Given it's shape, I would be careful with your flame size and keep a pot holder handy in case the handle gets too warm.

I usually don't bother to wash the kettle. I pour in hot water, pour out hot water, shake out the excess water, then put it upside-down on a drying rack, though it's probably a good idea to scrub it down once in a while in case something is starting to grow. I imagine the spout is nearly impossible to scrub.
author: glyphic
date: Revisado en los Estados Unidos el 21 de abril de 2013
